HEADLINE: With Dollar Still Weak, U.S. Bookings for Cruises in Europe Rise

BYLINE: By AUSTIN CONSIDINE

 BODY:
As the dollar continues to be weak against the euro, some cruise operators are promoting a vacation on the high seas as one of the best ways for Americans to see Europe this summer. That message seems to be paying off, with the numbers of people booking a European cruise up sharply. 
 ''You're prepaying in U.S. dollars, which gives you greater value,'' said Terry Dale, chief executive of Cruise Lines International Association, which represents 19 of the world's cruise lines. ''Last year, we had 1,900 European sailings, and in 2005 there's going to be over 2,200.'' 
 Even though some of the big cruise liners -- like Cunard's 2,620-passenger Queen Mary 2, which has four European itineraries this summer -- may already be benefiting from this trend, several small European cruise lines are trying to sweeten the deal by offering competitive discounts.
 For instance, Radisson Seven Seas Cruises, (800) 477-7500, www.rssc.com, has extended its 20 percent early-booking discount for its seven-night summer Baltic cruises to encompass the entire summer booking season (prices start at $3,996 a person in double occupancy), which runs until late August. Similar discounts are available for their Stockholm-Dover cruises: the 10-night cruise starting June 10 starts at $5,516 and includes free economy-class flights from North America or an additional $1,000 off the cost of the cruise; the 11-night cruise starting Aug. 20 is 30 percent off, starting at $4,966. All itineraries are on the 700-passenger Seven Seas Voyager. 
 A cruise on a river boat in Europe is another alternative to the experience on an ocean liner. France Vacations, (800) 332-5332, www.francevacations.net, has cut its rates by up to 30 percent aboard many of its cruise barges, which range in accommodation space from 3 cabins to 25. A 10-night trip through northern France aboard the 25-cabin Anacoluthe, which includes stops in Paris, Giverny and Bougival, is now $1,290 a person, down from $1,890.
 Looking ahead, Peter Deilmann Cruises, (800) 348-8287, www.deilmann-cruises.com, is offering a 15-night voyage at summer's end, Sept. 22, aboard the 513-passenger Deutschland, above, from Lisbon to France, for $2,826 -- 20 percent off the original price. They are also offering free air fare from 16 departure points on the East Coast, including New York and Miami, and rebates beginning at $100 for passengers flying out of other airports. AUSTIN CONSIDINE


CORRECTION-DATE: May 15, 2005

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Travel Advisory column on May 1 about promoting vacations at sea as a way to reduce the cost of a European vacation misstated the final destination of a 15-night voyage departing from Lisbon on Sept. 22 and offered by Peter Deilmann Cruises aboard the Deutschland. It is Venice, not France.
 Because of an editing error, the report also misstated the length of a river cruise through northern France aboard the Anacoluthe, offered by France Vacations. It is six nights, not 10.

Editors' Choice
Other recent books of particular interest

LOCAS: The Maggie and Hopey Stories, by Jaime Hernandez. (Fantagraphics, $49.95.) Two young Angelenas in a cumulative graphic novel that Hernandez began publishing in 1982.

OVERLORD: Poems, by Jorie Graham. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $22.95.) Politics and World War II, mediated by a major poet.

IN THE COMPANY OF CHEERFUL LADIES, by Alexander McCall Smith. (Pantheon, $19.95.) No. 6 in the Precious Ramotswe series about a kindly, plump female private eye in Botswana.

MY LIFE IN THE MIDDLE AGES: A Survivor's Tale, by James Atlas. (HarperCollins, $25.95.) An engaging memoir by a litbiz veteran who has been all the places and done all the things.

MEN OF TOMORROW: Geeks, Gangsters, and the Birth of the Comic Book, by Gerard Jones. (Basic Books, $26.) The creation and moral ordering of the comic book before World War II.

BUDDY DOES SEATTLE, by Peter Bagge. (Fantagraphics, paper, $14.95.) The first 15 issues of Bagge's ''Hate'' comics, with its slacker hero.

STRADIVARI'S GENIUS: Five Violins, One Cello and Three Centuries of Enduring Perfection, by Toby Faber. (Random House, $23.95.) Stories and studies about the Strads and their maker.

WITH BILLIE, by Julia Blackburn. (Pantheon, $25.) An account more anecdotal than interpretive of Billie Holiday, an artist who remains little known personally despite her famous work.

LADIES AND GENTLEMEN, THE BRONX IS BURNING: 1977, Baseball, Politics, and the Battle for the Soul of a City, by Jonathan Mahler. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) A narrative that captures the city's about-face from rot to rehab.

PETER BROOK: A Biography, by Michael Kustow. (St. Martin's, $27.95.) The development of the minimalist director of ''Lord of the Flies'' and the 1970-71 ''Midsummer Night's Dream.''

WHO SHE WAS: My Search for My Mother's Life, by Samuel G. Freedman. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A writer's take on his mother's frustrations as a Depression child from the Bronx.

HEADLINE: '55 and Out' Comes Home To Roost

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
INTEREST rates are ticking up while stock prices are trending down, eroding 401(k) savings. The president says that the Social Security system is in trouble, suggesting that the retirement age must be increased or that benefits must be scaled back for the well-off. 
 General Motors wants to rein in skyrocketing health costs for retirees. Retired coal miners have lost company-paid health insurance in bankruptcy proceedings. Even robust Fortune 500 companies are groaning under the weight of spiraling retirement costs. 
 For many middle-age, middle-class workers, retirement planning has become an exercise in high anxiety -- except perhaps for a group that makes up about 11 percent of the American work force: public employees. Public employment has always connoted a certain dull stability -- the promise of unexciting pay, but a secure pension. That modest idea has expanded over time. With the help of eager-to-please politicians, protective state laws and potent labor unions, many of the nation's state and local employees have only added to their benefits. They receive among the best, most rock-solid pensions and retirement health benefits of any workers in America. Many can retire before 65, with generous cost-of-living adjustments built into their pensions and full medical benefits for life. 
 More and more of them -- the baby boom bulge -- are doing just that, leaving states and localities scrambling to pay the cost, at taxpayer expense. In Oregon, state workers who joined the pension system before 1996 are guaranteed an annual 8 percent return on their pension accounts. In Pembroke Pines, Fla., police officers and firefighters can retire after 20 years with 80 percent of their pay. And in Philadelphia, some city workers, including the mayor, are eligible for early pension payments even when they remain on the city payroll.
 These obligations are playing havoc with state budgets. Four years ago, what one economist called ''a perfect storm'' of plummeting stock prices and weak tax revenues wrecked state budgets, and now scores of government pension funds remain in the red, prompting calls in statehouses for pension overhauls.
 A recent survey by the National Association of State Retirement Administrators found the nation's largest pension systems were collectively facing a $267 billion shortfall. A separate study released last month by Wilshire Associates, a consulting firm, found that the asset shortfall for state pension plans was worse than for corporate plans.
 No one, of course, is expecting governments to declare bankruptcy and dissolve their pension systems, the way many steel companies did in the 1980's and 1990's. But expensive pensions are squeezing budgets at a time when other costs -- education, transportation and particularly health care -- are rising rapidly. 
 In Rhode Island, where state payments into pension funds are projected to increase by 45 percent, or about $90 million, in the 2006 fiscal year, the governor has proposed increasing the retirement age and trimming cost-of-living increases for new workers. West Virginia, Mississippi and other states are considering selling bonds worth billions of dollars to close pension shortfalls. 
 And in California, which must pay $2.6 billion this year into the state plan, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger proposed -- then withdrew after loud protests from public employee unions -- a plan to shift workers from pension plans with guaranteed payments into 401(k)-style plans where workers assume greater investment risk.
 ''We're at a crossroads with public pension systems,'' said Sujit M. CanagaRetna, senior fiscal analyst with the Southern office of the Council of State Governments, which does research for state legislatures. ''It's a cumulative problem amounting to a fiscal tsunami for states.''
 Though government officials can justifiably blame the weak economy for many of their current problems, the downturn also shed light on missteps of the past.
 Just last week, the mayor of San Diego, Dick Murphy, resigned amid a scandal involving the city's deficit-ridden pension system. Federal officials are now investigating whether Mr. Murphy and other officials acted illegally in awarding generous new benefits to retirees while severely underfinancing pension funds. 
 In Missouri, the state legislature this year ended a policy that allowed appointees to quasi-judicial positions to retire with lucrative pensions after only short stints on the job. The policy caused an uproar when news reports revealed that the pension of a former state senator jumped to $47,600 from $28,700 after he served just five months as chairman of a labor commission. ''The vast majority of state employees don't get that kind of benefit,'' said State Representative Todd Smith, a sponsor of legislation that closed the loophole. ''There was a perception of abuse.'' 
 More commonly, cities are struggling to pay for decisions made years or even decades ago, whose compounding costs are coming due as the retirement pool swells. 
 A report issued last week by the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit fiscal research group, shows that New York City's contributions to its pension funds tripled in four years, to $2.3 billion in fiscal year 2004 from $615 million in 2000. The study also projected that the cost of retiree health benefits will rise to $6.3 billion in 2008, up 50 percent from 2004.
 The group calls for requiring city and state employees to pay half their retirement health insurance premiums, increasing the retirement age and moving toward 401(k)-style plans. But this is a mayoral election year, and commission officials are not optimistic about change. 
 State and local governments have historically defended generous retirement packages as crucial to recruiting and retaining good workers, arguing that public sector employees are typically paid less than similarly qualified private sector workers.
 ''Qualified people came to public sector work because of the benefits, and pensions were at the heart of that,'' said Gerald W. McEntee, president of the 1.4 million-strong American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees. ''But whenever we are in hard economic times, they come after workers in general, and public sector workers in particular. And they go after their pension funds.''
 But public pensions have also long been used by elected officials to curry favor with powerful unions. And pension sweeteners could be offered in lieu of wage increases when times were tight, since costs could be deferred. Nowhere has that been clearer than in West Virginia, where the Legislature for years expanded pension benefits for teachers without adequately increasing contributions into the pension system, leaving it with a $5 billion shortfall.
 ''You could say they did it to help retain and recruit teachers,'' said Judith Hale, president of the American Federation of Teachers of West Virginia. ''But they also did it to help them get elected.''
 In many ways, the debate over state pensions mirrors the debate over Social Security. Critics of public systems say a crisis is looming, while defenders contend the current problems are part of a cyclical downturn that will resolve itself as the economy improves.
 Officials with the National Association of State Retirement Administrators, for instance, say that most public pension funds are better managed than in the past, and that the huge shortfalls caused by the market downturn of 2001 have shrunk since the market began strengthening in 2003.
 Oregon reflects both sides of the argument. In 2003, the state trimmed benefits and sold bonds to close a projected $17 billion gap in its pension funds. By 2004, that deficit had shrunk to $6 billion because of improving investment returns, officials with the pension system said.
 But in March, the state's highest court threw out some of those cost-saving measures, prompting critics to contend that the next market downturn will send the state into financial turmoil once again.
 Yet such turmoil is not likely to worry state workers too much. ''We have never been in a year when people felt they wouldn't have a pension,'' said Ms. Hale of the West Virginia teachers' union. ''Because they knew the government was never going out of business.''

HEADLINE: And All the Trains Run on Time

BYLINE: By ALEX MINDLIN

 BODY:
FOR a fan of mass transit, life in a North Dakota monastery can be trying. ''We've got a new bus system here in Bismarck, and that's got eight routes and one bus an hour,'' said Elias Thienpont. ''To me that's not helpful.'' 
 As the resident technology expert at Assumption Abbey, in Richardton, N.D., where he is a monk, Brother Thienpont spends plenty of time on computers, and so in his spare time, he has begun revisiting a hobby from his Long Island boyhood -- drawing fantastic maps of the New York City subway system.
 Using computer graphics programs, Brother Thienpont charts a subway that exists only in his head. ''I work at the thing like a puzzle,'' he said. ''How do tracks cross or connect with each other? Exactly where are the stations to be built?'' One of his recent maps features a new line that links eastern Queens to Midtown, barreling through Queens on concrete risers and crossing the East River through a four-track tunnel.
 Brother Thienpont posts his maps to Web sites like railroad.net, where they can be examined by other fans of the hobby known as fantasy mapping, a kind of computer-aided daydreaming about subway routes. Message boards on these Web sites are thick with comments, countercomments and queries regarding fictional maps. In a typical post on railroad.net last June, one user expressed dismay with another user's map: ''The 8 line on a concrete viaduct over Randalls Island? No! Put it on the (now-abandoned) northernmost track of the Hell Gate Bridge!''
 Many fantasy mappers are ex-New Yorkers who, like Brother Thienpont, are trying to keep a connection to the subway they love. Some are motivated by frustration with existing service, like James Haynes, who added lines to the Bronx after growing up on Webster Avenue, far from any trains. ''I was trying to point out the improvements that could be made,'' he said.
 And all belong to the vast fraternity of subway fans, sometimes called ''foamers'' for the way they supposedly foam at the mouth. Mappers take pride in knowing enough about the subways to create a plausible map: a good mapper thinks about how many trains per hour can pass along a given segment of track, how much it costs to bore tunnels, where the storage yards are and which stations have the highest ridership.
 Then again, sometimes a mapper thinks about all that and chooses to disregard it. A mapper called ''matt1168'' recently posted a map on railroad.net that included a spur line to City Island, tunneled deep underground. ''Stations have 100-foot-high soaring roofs and colored lights,'' he wrote, ''and are elevator-only.'' When other mappers protested, he responded: ''That's why it's called a fantasy map.''
 As for Brother Thienpont, he is grateful to have an outlet for his ideas, because most of his fellow monks aren't particularly interested in transit. ''Occasionally I can pique someone's interest,'' he said, ''but usually they don't want to hear about it again.''

It would be hard to build a cut-and-cover tunnel underneath Central Park. The only logical way...would be to bore a hole with a tunnel boring machine, deep under the surface, so as not to distract Central Park itself at ground level.''3. Better Than the Bus''The Roosevelt Island bus is extremely slow and in many ways ineffective. This light rail would be a much faster, not to mention more economically and environmentally effective, way to get people from one end of Roosevelt Island to the other.''4. Harbor View''The R line has been extended over the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. I think there is room for a single track in the center of the lower level of the bridge. If not, maybe one lane could be taken away or something. Because of the single track, the service would start out being peak direction only. The only problem is that the trains going to Tottenville would have no place to go until the afternoon peak, and this could bring about a shortage of trains and lack of storage space.5. Finally, the 8 Train''The brand new 8 line runs from Queens Plaza to the Bronx via the N/W and a concrete structure over Randalls Island. It then runs with the 6 to Pelham Bay Park, where it branches off onto a new, deepbore, subway line to City Island.''6. The Long Island Subway''The V line has been extended to New Hyde Park, Long Island, via a subway with utilitarian island platform stations from Merrick Boulevard to Hempstead Avenue, and then on an embankment to New Hyde Park, with utilitarian side platform stations.''7. Dead End''Both the 105 Street station on the L line and the Beach 105th Street station on the A line have been eliminated due to low ridership. Stations such as Beach 105th Street (the least used station in the system) do little for the system but increase cost, when they get an average of just a few riders per day. On the other hand, we could also argue that constantly closing little-used stations would eventually lead to a meltdown of the entire system.''

HEADLINE: Giving Hollywood Funerals That Brooklyn Touch

BYLINE: By JAKE MOONEY

 BODY:
ON the second floor of the Bay Ridge Funeral Home in Brooklyn, on the desk of the owner, Alex Marchak, there sits a stack of prayer cards bearing words from the Book of John: ''I am the Resurrection and the Life; He who believes in me even if he die, shall live, and whoever lives and believes in me, shall never die.''
 The cards, dated Sept. 8, 2000, look just like the ones Mr. Marchak passes out at funerals almost every day. But these he has held onto, because they celebrate immortality of a different kind. ''In Loving Memory,'' they read, ''of Livia Soprano.'' 
 Ms. Soprano, the high-strung mother of her mob-boss son, Tony, lived and died entirely in a New Jersey of the mind, on the HBO series that bore her fictional family name. Even so, she was one of a string of famous customers for Mr. Marchak, who supplements his work as a funeral director with a healthy sideline in Hollywood magic, helping make television funerals look and feel more like the real thing.
 Mr. Marchak's office is scattered with mementos of past projects. ''They just sent me this from Whoopi Goldberg's show,'' he said with evident pride recently, pointing to a plaque and a thank-you letter. ''I built a casket for them.''
 Mr. Marchak, a gregarious 48-year-old native of Sunset Park, has spent more than enough time around funerals to qualify as an expert. He grew up above his family's funeral home at 19th Street and Fourth Avenue, and he followed his grandparents and his mother into the business.
 His got his start in show business later, at the height of 1970's disco fever. Mr. Marchak, a regular in Bay Ridge's disco scene, befriended a writer who was doing research for a movie about dancing. The movie became ''Saturday Night Fever,'' and Mr. Marchak, who served as an extra, is visible, if only blurrily, in the iconic disco image of a white-suited John Travolta pointing skyward.
 The work stood in sharp contrast to his day job. Mr. Marchak is typically comforting and solicitous with his funeral home clients, but the work takes its toll. ''The funeral business can be depressing,'' he said. ''All you're doing is dealing with people in the worst time of their life, every day.''
 By contrast, the movies became something to look forward to. Mr. Marchak now advertises in trade directories, under ''funeral supplies,'' and he has done work for the soap opera ''Guiding Light,'' the short-lived newspaper drama ''Deadline'' and the 1999 film ''Mickey Blue Eyes.'' He helped build an embalming room for ''Law & Order,'' and he once helped create an entire funeral home set so producers could crash a car through it. 
 He even had a brush with fame. Mr. Marchak was associate producer of a short 1997 film called ''Dearly Beloved,'' which he describes as a comedy about death. The film, set in a funeral home and with a cast that included Eric Stoltz, did well on the festival circuit but soon faded away. Years later, the similarly themed HBO series ''Six Feet Under'' became a hit and raised the public profile of funeral directors, while Mr. Marchak looked on from the sideline with a degree of envy.
 ''The project that I was involved with definitely would have been a better project than 'Six Feet Under,''' he said. ''It would have been great.''
 He still hopes for a big break. Until then, he has found his niche. He turns up on ''The Sopranos'' as an extra in scenes set in the Bada Bing nightclub; funeral-related props like coffins and urns are shipped off and returned; and every now and then the funeral home, which is also known as Trzaska Funeral Home, on Fourth Avenue near 76th Street, finds its way into an episode, in an exterior shot, or a brief scene showing people carrying a coffin, or a moment inside the chapel.
 And the funeral business itself is, happily for Mr. Marchak, recession-proof. Funerals these days are more personalized, he is finding, more of a celebration of life than they used to be. And Mr. Marchak is an attentive producer.
 Walking downstairs into his showroom, he paused by a display coffin and lifted a fringe of fabric hanging out the front. ''Every time I see funerals on TV, this part is always tucked in,'' he said, fussing with the material. ''You want to jump on the screen and tell them it should be out.''
 In the chapel, boxes of tissues stood at attention next to rows of empty padded chairs. At the front of the room there sat a kneeler and a pedestal for a coffin, momentarily unused. 
 ''They used this for 'Law & Order' up here,'' he said, walking briskly through the room. ''They like the old look. It's like a house.''

HEADLINE: The Greediest Generation

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF. 
E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

 BODY:
As a baby boomer myself, I can be blunt: We boomers won't be remembered as the ''Greatest Generation.'' Rather, we'll be scorned as the ''Greediest Generation.''
 Our influence has been huge. When boomer blood raged with hormones, we staged the sexual revolution and popularized the Pill. Now, with those hormones fading, we've popularized Viagra. 
 As we've aged, age discrimination has become a basis for lawsuits, and the most litigated right has become the right to die. The hot issue of the moment is Social Security, and the newest entitlement program is a prescription drug benefit for the elderly.
 Our slogan has gone from ''free love'' to ''free blood pressure medicine.''
 But I fear that we'll be remembered mostly for grabbing resources for ourselves, in such a way that the big losers will be America's children.
 Traditionally in America, the people most likely to be poor were the elderly. As recently as 1966, for example, 29 percent of Americans over 65 were below the poverty line, compared with only 18 percent of American children.
 But that same year, Medicare took effect to provide medical care for the elderly, and Social Security adjustments steadily reduced poverty among them. We were suitably embarrassed that old people were eating cat food or scavenging garbage cans for food, so we reallocated resources to the elderly.
 As of 2003, the share of elderly below the poverty line had fallen by two-thirds to 10 percent -- representing a huge national success. Retirement in America is no longer feared as a time of destitution, but anticipated as a time of comfort and leisure.
 On the other hand, the proportion of children below the poverty line is still 18 percent, the same as it was in 1966. And while almost all the elderly now have health insurance under Medicare, about 29 percent of children had no health insurance at all at some point in the last 12 months. 
 One measure of how children have tumbled as a priority in America is that in 1960 we ranked 12th in infant mortality among nations in the world, while now 40 nations have infant mortality rates better than ours or equal to it. We've also lost ground in child vaccinations: the United States now ranks 84th in the world for measles immunizations and 89th for polio.
 With boomers about to retire, I'm afraid that national priorities will be focused even more powerfully on the elderly rather than the young -- because it's the elderly who wield political clout.
 ''The elderly are retired, and it's easier to get them to go to rallies or write their congresspeople,'' notes Heather Boushey of the Center for Economic and Policy Research in Washington. ''Children can't vote, don't give money and have no power, and neither do their parents.''
 We boomers are also preying on children in a more insidious way: We're running up their debts, both by creating new entitlement programs and by running budget deficits today. Laurence Kotlikoff, an economist and fiscal expert who with Scott Burns wrote the excellent and scary book ''The Coming Generational Storm,'' calls this ''fiscal child abuse.''
 The book says that the Treasury Department commissioned a study by two economists of the United States' long-term liabilities, for inclusion in the 2004 federal budget. The study found that the government faces a present value ''fiscal gap'' -- the excess of expected payments over expected revenues -- of $51 trillion. That's 11 times our official national debt and also greater than our total net worth, meaning that in some sense we're bankrupt.
 Not surprisingly, the Bush administration took a look at the study, blanched, and declined to publish it.
 In coming years, we'll hear appeals for better nursing homes, for more Alzheimer's research and for more wheelchair-accessible office buildings, and those are good causes. But remember that American children are almost twice as likely as the elderly to live in poverty, and that you get much more bang for the buck vaccinating a child than paying for open-heart surgery. 
 The solution is not to force the elderly to get by on cat food again. But we boomers need to resist the narcissistic impulse to ladle out more resources for ourselves. Our top domestic priorities should be to ensure that all children get health care and to get our fiscal house in order.
 Otherwise, we boomers may earn a place in history as the worst generation.

HEADLINE: A Roll Call Around the World In Mansfield School District

BYLINE: By GAIL BRACCIDIFERRO

 BODY:
SHAMIM PATWA remembers sometimes feeling isolated growing up in a northern New Jersey town where hers was the only family from India. Ms. Patwa said she didn't want her children to relive those experiences in the rural town of Mansfield.
 ''It was a shock to come here at first,'' said Ms. Patwa, who was born in India and came to Mansfield, in eastern Connecticut, about a decade ago as a University of Connecticut doctoral degree student. ''People talked about septic tanks, field mice and well water. I worried about this being a small town.'' 
 What she discovered, however, was a town that not only is ethnically, racially, economically and religiously diverse, but one whose public school system is determined to build on this advantage. It does this through a foreign language program that extends to its youngest students, multicultural celebrations, cultural exchanges and trips for both students and teachers, assistantships aimed at bringing minority teachers to the district and a keen sensitivity to racial, ethnic and religious differences.
 ''Three of the 13 kids in my daughter's third-grade classroom are Muslim,'' said Ms. Patwa, who has served on the town's school board for six years. ''When my daughter mentions names, they are from all over the world.''
 District statistics for the 2003-4 school year show that nearly 10 percent of Mansfield's students have a non-English home language and about 17 percent are members of a minority group. In the 37 other school districts that the state Department of Education identified as having demographics similar to Mansfield's, an average of only 1.5 percent of the students have non-English home languages, the statistics show.
 Mansfield Middle School's principal, Jeffrey L. Cryan, said the minority population in town is also on the upswing.
 ''We did a five-year comparison and there was a 5 percent growth in the minority population,'' he said.
 Gordon Schimmel, Manfield's school superintendent, said there were usually 15 to 25 different home languages spoken among the students in kindergarten through grade 8.
 ''We have an international community as a result of being a university town,'' said Mr. Schimmel, who has been the superintendent for 18 years. ''That is one of the things that attracted me here. I had been a Peace Corps volunteer.'' Mansfield includes the community of Storrs, home to the main campus of the University of Connecticut, and is also close to Eastern Connecticut State University in Willimantic.
 While Mansfield may be a rural island of diversity in a region where most school districts are overwhelmingly populated by white middle-class Christian students, the town's school administrators and the Board of Education have also decided they needed to go beyond the simple fact of accepting that diversity exists.
 ''They've done a lot of good things,'' said William A. Howe, consultant for multicultural education for the state's Department of Education. ''They actively see it as a strength. We've been working to promote exactly the kind of work that's going on in Mansfield.'' 
 A visit to one of the town's schools is a United Nations experience. The ethnic and racial diversity is evident among the students themselves. Also, many signs are posted in English and another language, bulletin boards promote coming international celebrations, information is posted for parents about multicultural programs in the region, and classrooms bloom with decorations from cultures ranging from Mexican to Native American and French Canadian. 
 A commitment to teaching foreign languages is one way the district works to demonstrate that Mansfield is part of a global community. Mansfield is one of only five Connecticut towns with similar demographics that teach foreign languages in the primary grades, according to Department of Education statistics. Statewide, 28 town or regional school districts teach foreign languages to primary-grade students.
 In Mansfield, all children in grades two through five learn Spanish, Mr. Schimmel said. Sixth graders have an opportunity to sample four foreign languages: Spanish, French, German and Latin.
 Students in grades seven and eight choose to concentrate in one of these four languages.
 Kathy Siddons, whose high-spirited Spanish lessons combine traditional foreign-language vocabulary such as weather terms, numbers, colors and shapes with plenty of student participation, singing and movement, teaches students in grades two through five at the Dorothy C. Goodwin Elementary School, just west of the UConn campus. She said she was hired 10 years ago as the town's first elementary school foreign-language teacher. 
 There is now a Spanish teacher at each of the town's three elementary schools and four foreign-language teachers at the town's middle school.
 ''There was a ground swell of support from parents and the Board of Education,'' said Gayle Hightower, who teaches a middle-school Latin class. ''They really wanted this.''
 Twelve Connecticut school districts offer Latin to middle-school students. 
 ''I have kids waiting in line for this,'' Ms. Hightower said of her Latin classes. ''Part of that is that it has become a tradition here.''
 Beyond the study foreign languages and cultures, the school system encourages international trips and exchanges. For 12 years the middle school has had a sister school in Germany, and students from each school have visited the other on several occasions, said Mr. Cryan, the middle school principal. Mansfield students also frequently write to international pen pals and both teachers and students also travel to places such as Quebec, Chile, Ukraine and China on school trips. 
 ''This expands our children's sense of the world,'' said Mr. Cryan, who spent time earlier this winter at a middle school in China. ''When I was a kid, I never thought I would go to China or have a professional relationship there, but I found we have so much in common.''
 The school district also has recognized the importance of recruiting minority faculty members and for about six years has supported assistantships for two minority students from UConn who are studying to be teachers, Mr. Schimmel said. The UConn students work for 30 hours a week with a regular teacher on a project in the Mansfield schools, he said.
 ''We've put up $13,000 a year for this, and UConn matches that amount,'' Mr. Schimmel said. ''I don't know any other school district that has used local funds for such a thing.''
 Ms. Patwa said board members, administrators, teachers and students all are open to new multicultural ideas, she said.
 ''I do remember racist remarks as a child, but I can't imagine that happening here,'' she said. ''Here there is a spirit of there being a larger world. It is very natural.''

HEADLINE: Confidence Is Beginning To Wear Thin

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
GUESS what? That R word is sneaking into conversations again.
 Some economists and market analysts are daring to utter ''recession,'' although they are not predicting one -- yet. It is a sign of how quickly confidence in the economy has eroded. Just a month ago, the outlook for growth was still quite robust. 
 ''Is it time to dust off the R word?'' asked Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at Johnson Illington Advisors, as the stock market tumbled last Thursday. ''My answer is no. But it's not too early to worry.''
 With Federal Reserve policy makers scheduled to meet on Tuesday and the report on April employment due on Friday, this could be a pivotal week for the R word, even if it is still being tossed about as black humor, not stark reality.
 Fed policy makers are expected to raise their benchmark federal funds rate by a quarter-point, to 3 percent. It would be the eighth quarter-point increase since the end of last June.
 Investors will be more interested, however, in what policy makers say in their statement about recent signs that the economy is slowing. If growth is slowing, investors will also want to know if they can worry less about inflation.
 On employment, Wall Street analysts are predicting that 173,000 jobs were created in April, according to Bloomberg News. That is up from the unexpectedly weak gain of 110,000 in March. Economists pointed to the March figure as one of the first signs of slower growth. 
 While economists say that there is no recession on the horizon, some growth forecasts fell sharply last week. Goldman Sachs reduced its forecast for second-quarter growth to 3 percent from 4 percent after a report on the first-quarter gross domestic product pointed to a slowdown ahead. Morgan Stanley trimmed its already weaker forecast for this quarter to less than 3 percent from 3.2 percent.

OTHER DATA -- On Monday, the Institute for Supply Management will release its manufacturing index. Analysts forecast that it slipped to 55 in April from 55.2 in March. (A reading of more than 50 means that the manufacturing sector is still growing.)
 A much bigger decline than that, combined with a weaker-than-expected jobs report, would be a nightmare for stocks.
 But it would be a help for the bond market, where bad news is often good. Such a combustible mixture could send the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note back down to near 4 percent, an unlikely prospect just six weeks ago, when it was 4.64 percent.

HEADLINE: The War We Could Have Won

BYLINE: By Stephen J. Morris. 
Stephen J. Morris, a fellow at Johns Hopkins University's School of Advanced International Studies, is writing a book on the Vietnam War in the Nixon years.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THE Vietnam War is universally regarded as a disaster for what it did to the American and Vietnamese people. However, 30 years after the war's end, the reasons for its outcome remain a matter of dispute. 
 The most popular explanation among historians and journalists is that the defeat was a result of American policy makers' cold-war-driven misunderstanding of North Vietnam's leaders as dangerous Communists. In truth, they argue, we were fighting a nationalist movement with great popular support. In this view, ''our side,'' South Vietnam, was a creation of foreigners and led by a corrupt urban elite with no popular roots. Hence it could never prevail, not even with a half-million American troops, making the war ''unwinnable.'' 
 This simple explanation is repudiated by powerful historical evidence, both old and new. Its proponents mistakenly base their conclusions on the situation in Vietnam during the 1950's and early 1960's and ignore the changing course of the war (notably, the increasing success of President Richard Nixon's Vietnamization strategy) and the evolution of South Vietnamese society (in particular the introduction of agrarian reforms).
 For all the claims of popular support for the Vietcong insurgency, far more South Vietnamese peasants fought on the side of Saigon than on the side of Hanoi. The Vietcong were basically defeated by the beginning of 1972, which is why the North Vietnamese launched a huge conventional offensive at the end of March that year. During the Easter Offensive of 1972 -- at the time the biggest campaign of the war -- the South Vietnamese Army was able to hold onto every one of the 44 provincial capitals except Quang Tri, which it regained a few months later. The South Vietnamese relied on American air support during that offensive.
 If the United States had provided that level of support in 1975, when South Vietnam collapsed in the face of another North Vietnamese offensive, the outcome might have been at least the same as in 1972. But intense lobbying of Congress by the antiwar movement, especially in the context of the Watergate scandal, helped to drive cutbacks of American aid in 1974. Combined with the impact of the world oil crisis and inflation of 1973-74, the results were devastating for the south. As the triumphant North Vietnamese commander, Gen. Van Tien Dung, wrote later, President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam was forced to fight ''a poor man's war.''
 Even Hanoi's main patron, the Soviet Union, was convinced that a North Vietnamese military victory was highly unlikely. Evidence from Soviet Communist Party archives suggests that, until 1974, Soviet military intelligence analysts and diplomats never believed that the North Vietnamese would be victorious on the battlefield. Only political and diplomatic efforts could succeed. Moscow thought that the South Vietnamese government was strong enough to defend itself with a continuation of American logistical support. The former Soviet charge d'affaires in Hanoi during the 1970's told me in Moscow in late 1993 that if one looked at the balance of forces, one could not predict that the South would be defeated. Until 1975, Moscow was not only impressed by American military power and political will, it also clearly had no desire to go to war with the United States over Vietnam. But after 1975, Soviet fear of the United States dissipated.
 During the war the Soviets despised their North Vietnamese ''friends'' (the term of confidential bureaucratic reference, rather than ''comrades''). Indeed, Henry A. Kissinger's accounts of his dealings, as Nixon's national security adviser, with President Thieu are models of respect when compared with the bitter Soviet accounts of their difficulties with their counterparts. 
 In secret internal reports, Hanoi-based Soviet diplomats regularly complained about the deceitfulness of the North Vietnamese, who concealed strategic planning from their more powerful patron. In a 1972 report to Moscow, the Soviet ambassador even complained that although Marshal Pavel Batitsky, commander of the Soviet Air Defense Forces, had visited Hanoi earlier that year and completed a major military aid agreement, North Vietnamese leaders did not inform him of the imminent launch date of their Easter Offensive.
 What is also clear from Soviet archival sources is that those who believed that North Vietnam had more than national unification on its mind were right: Its leaders were imbued with a sense of their ideological mission -- not only to unify Vietnam under Communist Party rule, but also to support the victory of Communists in other nations. They saw themselves as the outpost of world revolution in Southeast Asia and desired to help Communists in Cambodia, Laos, Thailand and elsewhere. 
 Soviet archives show that after the war ended in 1975, with American power in retreat, Hanoi used part of its captured American arsenal to support Communist revolutions around the world. In 1980 some of these weapons were shipped via Cuba to El Salvador. This dimension of Vietnamese behavior derived from a deep commitment to the messianic internationalism of Marxist-Leninist ideology. 
 Vietnam today is not the North Vietnam of 1955, 1965 or 1975. Like post-Mao China it has retreated from totalitarianism to authoritarianism. It has reformed its economy and its foreign policy to become more integrated into the world. But those changes were not inevitable and would not necessarily have occurred had Mikhail Gorbachev not ascended to power in Moscow, and had the Soviet Union and its empire not collapsed. Nor would these changes necessarily have occurred had China not provided a new cultural model for Vietnam to follow, as it has for centuries. 
 Precisely because Vietnam has changed for the better, we need to recognize what a profoundly ideological and aggressive totalitarian regime we faced three, four and five decades ago. And out of respect for the evidence of history, we need to recognize what happened in the 1970's and why.
 In 1974-75, the United States snatched defeat from the jaws of victory. Hundreds of thousands of our Vietnamese allies were incarcerated, and more than a million driven into exile. The awesome image of the United States was diminished, and its enemies were thereby emboldened, drawing the United States into new conflicts by proxy in Afghanistan, Africa and Latin America. And the bitterness of so many American war veterans, who saw their sacrifices so casually demeaned and unnecessarily squandered, haunts American society and political life to this day.

HEADLINE: Americans Are Flocking to Canada's Pristine Gulf Islands

BYLINE: By CAITLIN KELLY

DATELINE: Salt Spring Island, British Columbia 

 BODY:
JUST 35 minutes after leaving Vancouver, the small white ferry glides into Fulford Harbor, one of two entrances to the island. The largest of Canada's southern Gulf Islands, Salt Spring offers 70 square miles of lush green fields and steep, pine-forested hillsides, and only three towns: Ganges, Vesuvius and Fulford Harbor. 
 The few roads are narrow and winding, and local hitchhikers, including children, often rely on their neighbors for transport, because there is no bus service. Canadians have long revered Salt Spring as a pristine refuge for the eccentric and creative. 
 It was founded in 1859 by African-Americans and Portuguese who carved out homesteads in the fertile valleys. Tiny St. Paul's Catholic Church was built largely with labor from the Hawaiian community that was established in the late 1880's. In the 1970's, Americans avoiding service in the Vietnam War arrived and put down roots. And for many years, Americans in search of affordable second homes, and looking forward to retirement, have also chosen this island -- a rarity with year-round ferry and seaplane service, a hospital and more urban amenities than neighboring islands.
 But times are changing, and changing fast. Fueled by the still-strong American dollar (around $1.20 to the Canadian dollar) quick leaps in real estate prices and new housing development, tensions are growing between longtime islanders desperate to preserve their quiet way of life, and real estate agents, developers and investors who know a good thing when they see it.
 The island's population has tripled in 30 years, and growth presents many challenges, from increased water pollution of its eight lakes and a falling water table that leaves some wells dry by summer's end to a school week that has shrunk to four days because of a budget crunch.
 For years, Salt Spring was an affordable haven. But now a cottage with water views is 700,000 Canadian dollars, (about $560,000) more than double its 320,000 Canadian dollars price of five years ago. That rate of increase is typical for properties on or near the water, brokers say. 
 Two forces have accelerated the surge in prices: there are few properties to buy and two layers of government place restrictions on development. 
 Many of the new buyers are Americans. ''There's been a huge increase in the past three years in the number of Americans coming here, which we predicted on Sept. 12, 2001,'' says Dick Stubbs, the provincial government's local building inspector.
 John Sorensen, a developer whose town houses in the town of Ganges sell for 260,000 Canadian dollars to 420,000 Canadian dollars (or around $208,700 to $337,100) says half of his buyers are from the United States. 
 Li Read, a broker in business since 1989 on the island, says that 60 to 70 percent of her clients are now American. ''I think, after 9/11, people began to revise their life scripts,'' she said. ''We've always had U.S. buyers, and people who prefer to invest in real estate, and people who want to get away from it all, but now there's a lot of things coming into play.''
 In addition to coming from the United States, buyers are coming from the prosperous economies of Ontario and Alberta within Canada, and from the United Kingdom.
 Surging real estate values are also shutting out the very people who have built the island, often literally. ''Every morning on the ferry arriving from Vancouver Island, you'll see at least 40 guys coming to do construction; they live off the island but work here,'' said Myles Wilson, a broker who has lived on the island for 30 years. For blue-collar workers, this island paradise has become a place for the wealthy, not a place to raise their own children. 
 ''Salt Spring is getting out of reach for the first-time buyer,'' Mr. Wilson said.
 Houses on Vancouver Island, an easy commute, cost 129,000 Canadian dollars.
 Peter Levitt, 59, a poet who had been living in California, moved to Salt Spring in 2000 with his wife, Shirley Graham, a psychologist, and their 8-year-old son, Tai. That year, the Canadian currency was even weaker in relation to the American dollar than it is now. They bought a 2,800-square foot home with a separate 400-square foot studio and an 850-square-foot barn for 400,000 Canadian dollars, then about $259,000. ''We could not move here now,'' Mr. Levitt said. He had heard about Salt Spring from a friend, and after visiting for several years, moved here, a change made easier by his wife's dual American-Canadian citizenship. 
 While Americans can easily buy property here, they must maintain residence in the United States, and can stay in Canada each year for a total of only six months minus a day. Those wishing to become full-time residents must apply for landed immigrant status, which can take up to three years. 
 Since settling in Salt Spring, Mr. Levitt said, he has been disheartened by some of the changes. Development-related pollution has so contaminated his local water source, a lake facing his house, that his family must now drink bottled water. ''I attended a water meeting the other day,'' he said. ''There were four of us in the room, and between us we sit on 15 committees, all trying to fight for the environment here. It's gotten completely out of hand.'' 
 Caught between the competing demands of real estate professionals and part-time residents and frustrated, less-affluent locals is the Islands Trust, a federation of local governments created in 1974 with the explicit mandate to ''preserve and protect'' the more than 400 Gulf Islands. 
 Depending on whom you ask, the trust is either moving too quickly, allowing overdevelopment and associated environmental degradation and density -- or too slowly, failing to address the pressing, growing demands for affordable housing and increased services for an aging population.All development must be approved by the Islands Trust and the Capital Regional District, a branch of municipal government of the city of Victoria, on Vancouver Island. Salt Spring, which is unincorporated, has no mayor or city council. It elects two representatives to the Islands Trust and one to the Capital Regional District to speak for its interests.
 One big development is Channel Ridge, a 1,400-acre project that will contain as many as 305 houses by 2010. 
 Some residents view with alarm the increasing density and demand for services. ''Water is finite,'' Mr. Levitt said. ''On an island there is only so much space, only so much water. With added density also comes traffic, air pollution and parking issues. Can this community sustain itself?''

Because of an editing error, the National Perspectives article last Sunday, about development on Salt Spring Island, in British Columbia, misstated the time it takes to travel to the island from Vancouver. The ferry takes two to three hours, depending on the route, not 35 minutes. It takes about 35 minutes to travel from Swartz Bay on Vancouver Island to Fulford Harbor on Salt Spring Island.

HEADLINE: It's Not Just About the Baseball

BYLINE: By DAVE CALDWELL

DATELINE: LAKEWOOD 

 BODY:
A NEW blue Hawaiian-print shirt hangs on a bat in a corner of Geoff Brown's office. He is the general manager of the Lakewood BlueClaws, the most popular minor league baseball team in New Jersey, and the shirt represents a kind of pledge.
 Although the BlueClaws have drawn almost 2 million fans in their first four seasons, Mr. Brown wants to keep the look fresh, make his employees stand out in a crowd and remind fans that they are only 10 miles from the Shore.
 The crowds at FirstEnergy Park in Lakewood, where the BlueClaws opened their fifth season on April 7, are as large as ever. While teams in Newark and Atlantic City have struggled to lure fans to their games, the BlueClaws have been the state's top-drawing team among its eight minor league teams in each of their four full seasons. 
 Last season, for instance, the BlueClaws drew 440,521 fans -- nearly 40,000 more than the Trenton Thunder, who are a rung higher on the minor league ladder, and more than twice as many as the independent Newark Bears, whose new ballpark sits in the middle of the largest city in the state.
 Even when attendance dipped at BlueClaws games by 1.2 percent in 2004 from the previous season -- they were still playing to 99.8 percent of capacity -- it dropped by 9.4 percent at Newark Bears games and by 20.3 percent at Atlantic City Surf games.
 ''There are a lot of new ballparks in the minor leagues, but there are a lot of teams that don't fill a new ballpark like they do,'' said Kurt Landes, general manager for the Hagerstown Suns, an affiliate of the Mets and one of the BlueClaws' South Atlantic League opponents. ''A lot of people who get new ballparks rest on their laurels.''
 If a fan has a question or a complaint, Mr. Brown wants to hear it. So every BlueClaws' employee wears a new blue Hawaiian-print shirt to the new ballpark, which opened in spring 2001 and is distinguished by a crisp brick facade and imposing entrance.
 Good will and marketing gimmicks aside, the BlueClaws' popularity is a bit mystifying since they have had just one winning season, and quickly dropped below .500 so far this season. 
 ''The level of play on the field doesn't determine what we do,'' Mr. Brown said during a recent interview in his office.
 What the BlueClaws can do is weigh down their 70-game home schedule with promotions, and they have done so with a flair that would shame a boardwalk pitchman. For instance, the 34-year-old Mr. Brown is currently excited about the giveaway of a 10 percent share of a locally bred racehorse at Thursday's game, another franchise first.
 So while the team has come up short in bringing home a championship, its persistence in providing something new and alluring for fans has helped the BlueClaws win the South Atlantic League Club Merit Award three times. And in 2002 the team won the Larry McPhail Award, given to the minor league team with the best promotional effort.
 Still, the BlueClaws' full-time staff of 25 knows it has no time to rest on its accomplishments. Besides offering a different promotion every night, the team offers a cavorting yellow fuzzy mascot named Buster, a picnic area and a food court, lucky-number drawings, seat upgrades, food giveaways and a race among fans wearing gigantic eyeballs. And the team not only has a flashy Web site (www.blueclaws.com), but a theme song, ''BlueClaws Rock.''
 Along with the task of selling more tickets, which range in price from $6 to $9, and giving families their money's worth comes the responsibility of tightening the BlueClaws' ties with the community.

Lakewood's Ups and Downs
 Lakewood --in northern Ocean County with a diverse population of 60,000 -- was struggling economically until the state made the township an urban enterprise zone in 1994. Indeed, even Lakewood's biggest boosters say time had passed the town by.
 ''For a lot of years, a lot of companies would try to hide the fact that they were in Lakewood," said State Senator Robert W. Singer, whose district includes Lakewood.
 These days, the BlueClaws have so many sponsors that they had to build two new billboards -- beyond the outfield fence but visible from the stands -- to accommodate all the advertising. And Senator Singer insists that Exit 89 of the Garden State Parkway might not have been built if the BlueClaws had not been so successful.
 For their part, the BlueClaws want to be regarded as just as important a part of summertime entertainment at the Jersey Shore as the Six Flags Great Adventure theme park or the beaches, where airplanes drone overhead with banners promoting BlueClaws games.
 ''It takes a couple of years to get on the map for tourists,'' Mr. Brown said.
 It takes easily as long to sort out the various levels of minor league ball being played around the state. Of the eight minor league teams in New Jersey, the BlueClaws are one of only three affiliated with a major league club -- the BlueClaws with the Phillies, the Trenton Thunder with the Yankees and the New Jersey Cardinals with St. Louis.
 There are six steps to the major leagues: rookie, short-season Class A, low Class A, advanced Class A, Class AA and Class AAA. The Blue Claws are a low Class A team, the third step; the Cardinals, of the New York-Penn League, are a short-season Class A team; and the Thunder, of the Eastern League, are a Class AA team.
 The other five teams in the state are independents, made up of former major league players or prospects who hope to latch on to a big-league team or affiliate. The Newark Bears, Somerset Patriots, Atlantic City Surf and Camden Riversharks are members of the Atlantic League; the New Jersey Jackals are in the Can-Am League.
 In each of their four seasons, the BlueClaws have drawn at least 440,000 fans despite the fact that they and a team in Lake County, Ohio, are the only franchises in the South Atlantic League north of the Mason-Dixon Line. 
 ''I don't think the distance is as much of a factor as it was years ago,'' John H. Moss, president of the South Atlantic League, said in a telephone interview from his office in Kings Mountain, N.C. ''You just don't have the rivalries you did years ago. I've been around a few seasons, and we had to go to where the markets and the facilities were.''
 Yet just because New Jersey is the most densely populated state in the country, that does not guarantee a packed house at a minor league ballgame. The BlueClaws, the Thunder (whose average attendance last season was 6,095) and the Patriots ( average attendance, 5,376) were the only teams in the state to average 5,000 fans at each game last season.

Bears Are Struggling
 In fact, the beleaguered Newark Bears averaged only 2,746 fans at home games last season, down from 3,032 in 2003. And the attendance at home games for the two other Atlantic League teams also dropped: the Surf attracted an average of 2,054 fans last season, down from 2,576, and the Riversharks drew an average 4,309 down from 4,547.
 The Patriots gained 215 fans a game last year. But the New Jersey Cardinals, in Augusta, and the New Jersey Jackals, in Little Ferry, each drew an average of fewer than 3,000 fans, though they do play a shorter schedule.
 John Clark, the assistant general manager for the BlueClaws, said unpredictable weather last season caused the slight dip in attendance. As Tony Torre, the New Jersey Cardinals general manager, said, there is no way around a poor forecast ''unless you have a dome.''
 Of course, on a beautiful summer night with children to care for and a few dollars to spend, it's not just about the baseball. 
 FirstEnergy Park -- a smart-looking stadium with seating for 6,588 fans and wide, grassy banks just beyond the outfield fence that can accommodate another 6,500 -- has had several face lifts in its five years. 
 The park was built to be a gathering place, and has slowly become one. For instance, a room on the second floor is rented out for business meetings. In July, when the BlueClaws are on the road, a three-on-three basketball tournament is scheduled. And on Fridays in spring and summer, a flea market is held outside the park.
 ''It boosts civic pride quite tremendously,'' said Sheldon Wolpin, chairman of the Lakewood Heritage Commission.
 At the turn of the 20th century, before the days of airplanes, Lakewood was a bustling winter resort with more than 100 hotels and thriving shops. The town was a playground for the rich and famous who took horse-drawn carriages or the train from New York. John D. Rockefeller had an estate in Lakewood that later became Ocean County Park.
 Then, in 1944, a prominent rabbi named Aron Kotler moved to Lakewood from Eastern Europe, and a large Orthodox Jewish community evolved that still numbers about 20,000. But after World War II, travel became immeasurably easier, and hotels and businesses began to close as vacationers opted for more exotic destinations.
 ''The attraction of Lakewood as a winter resort kind of went downhill,'' Mr. Wolpin said.
 In the late 1990's, downtown Lakewood went through a revitalization, and tenants began to fill a 2,200-acre industrial park near the parkway. The next step was to create a focal point in a town in which baseball had been stitched into the fabric of life.

A Township 'Into Sports'
 "Everybody around here seems to be into sports, especially into baseball," said Craig DiBella, the general manager at Pine Belt Chevrolet, a BlueClaws sponsor.
 In 1896 and 1897 and again in 1943-45, the New York Giants -- who would later move to San Francisco -- held spring training here. And as recently as 1975 and 1998, teams from Lakewood and nearby Toms River won the Little League World Series.
 Although a wave of minor league expansion swept past Monmouth and Ocean counties in the late 1990's, the township was convinced -- with nearly 1.5 million people living within a 35-minute drive -- that it could support a team. 
 ''The old expression, 'Build it, and they will come,' may have worked in the movies with a cornfield, but when it comes right down to it, you still need a market,'' said Russell Corby, the executive director of the Lakewood Development Corporation.
 The township had a spot for its ballpark -- a 250-acre plot of pineland adjacent to the industrial park. Civic leaders hoped that a ballpark could become the centerpiece of a sprawling office complex.
 ''I would say, prior to 1999, you probably didn't hear too many people say, 'I'm going to Lakewood tonight,' for any reason,'' Mr. Corby said.
 The township approved a bond sale that over 10 years would raise the $20 million needed to build the ballpark. In the meantime, the town had begun to look for a team. 
 Senator Singer said that Lakewood wanted to have a farm club rather than an independent team like the ones in Atlantic City, Camden, Newark and Somerset. That way, he said, the risk would be substantially lower.
 The parent clubs are responsible for paying the salaries of the managers, coaches and players they send to their farm clubs. The affiliates, in turn, receive good young prospects. The BlueClaws, for instance, have only one player born before 1980.
 ''People definitely want to see these guys when they're pups,'' said Mr. Brown, who worked for the Thunder, the Yankees' Class AA affiliate, when Nomar Garciaparra played for the team in 1994.
 As a major-league farm club, said John Clark, the assistant general manager for the BlueClaws, there is a little bit more legitimacy: ''The guys playing for us were drafted by the Phillies, and the guys playing for the other teams we play were also drafted by big league clubs.''
 Had Lakewood only been able to attract an independent team, Senator Singer said flatly that the ballpark would not have been built. But that failed to become an issue, he said, because the project began almost immediately to attract the attention of minor league clubs.
 The ownership of the Thunder in Trenton, 40 miles west of Lakewood, took an interest. And the Phillies, who owned a struggling team in Piedmont, N.C., wanted to move it to New Jersey, where it would be guided by the Thunder ownership.

Management Team Is Born
 Next, Mr. Brown, who was working in the front office of the Yankees' former Class AA farm club in Norwich, Conn., was hired in November 1999. Then Mr. Clark, who worked with him in Norwich, joined him in Lakewood.
 They set up an office near the Lakewood airport, where they had one telephone and 40 feet of cord. As Mr. Brown remembered with a smile, ''Whoever ended up with the phone on their desk had to be the secretary.''
 Today the BlueClaws have a spacious office in the ballpark, and the two men have offices with windows that look out on the diamond.
 And last month, the developers of the business park announced that they had signed their first tenant not too far from that very diamond.
 ''This becomes an exciting place you want to be near,'' Senator Singer boasted.
 But the public is fickle, and the BlueClaws know they have to keep hawking their product. Besides the racehorse giveaway, the team is inviting fans to bring their dogs -- who can roam in the grass outside the outfield fence -- to next Saturday's game against the Hickory Crawdads.
 Before the home opener on April 7, the team saluted 20 area residents who had served in the military in Iraq. For Mr. Brown, the ceremony was more touching than he could have imagined.
 ''Everyone was so hyped up, we gave up five runs in the first inning,'' he said with a smile.
 The BlueClaws went on to lose, 10-2. But 6,804 fans came out, and the legion of employees in new blue Hawaiian-print shirts reported that everyone had a good time -- according to plan.

HEADLINE: Bid Leaders Share Fraternal Bond, and a Furious Pace

BYLINE: By LYNN ZINSER

 BODY:
Sebastian Coe has endured trying moments in the job of leading London's bid for the 2012 Olympics, with its public relations tempests and punishing travel schedule, but none quite so trying as the day of his mother's funeral. As hard as it was to mourn her death, he immediately bade his family goodbye and left for a 23-hour plane trip to Australia to help pitch London's bid to a gathering of International Olympic Committee members in early April.
 Exhausted emotionally and physically, Coe walked into the lobby of his hotel in Brisbane, and the first person he saw was the NYC2012 founder, Daniel L. Doctoroff. They sat together for 15 minutes, stealing a break in their frenzied schedules simply to empathize. 
 ''He was very understanding; he had lost a parent recently, too,'' Coe said in a telephone interview from London last week. ''It was a great display of humanity.''
 The five men leading the bids for the 2012 Olympic finalist cities are an unusual peer group, sharing what has become a grueling job, only one of which will end happily when the I.O.C. picks the 2012 city on July 6. The task of selling 117 I.O.C. members on their city falls largely on these five men.
 Coe, a two-time Olympic 1,500-meter champion, plugs London tirelessly. Doctoroff, who doubles as New York's deputy mayor, does the same for his city. Paris leans on Philippe Baudillon, Madrid on Feliciano Mayoral and Moscow on Valery P. Shantsev, the city's vice mayor.
 ''We could create a trade union of bidders,'' Baudillon said jokingly during a telephone interview.
 In the new era of I.O.C. rules, members are not allowed to travel to the bidding cities, an attempt to avoid the corruption unearthed in Salt Lake City's bid. So wooing the hearts and votes of the committee members requires the bid leaders to chase them around the world, to every event deemed an appropriate meeting. And with the competition so fierce among five powerhouse cities, no one dares miss even the smallest opportunity.
 The five men hopscotch the globe in pursuit of votes, squeezing sales pitches into every meeting, no matter how short. Their schedules look like a flight attendant's.
 Doctoroff, long familiar with an arduous work schedule in his years as an investment banker, has given up wearing a watch. One day last month, before leaving for another trip, he put one on but had not bothered to set it. At 11:45 a.m., he glanced at it. It read 6:15.
 ''I barely know what time zone I'm in, so I'm always waking up at funny hours,'' he said. ''But I love it. I can honestly say I have not regretted once the decision to do what I'm doing. People say, 'How do you keep going?' But I say, 'When you love what you do, it's a lot easier.'''
 The effort has heated up over the past year, with each city required to develop and file its bid book, play host to the evaluation commission and plunge into the most important work: persuading the I.O.C. members who will decide their fates.
 This is the part that got the I.O.C. into trouble before awarding the 2002 Winter Games to Salt Lake City: the process devolved into a free-for-all of personal favors. The committee responded by expelling 10 members and rewriting its bidding rules. In came the restrictions on when and how bid leaders could approach members. The evaluation commission was created to judge the bids and to help the larger body choose.
 ''The I.O.C. is trying to make sure the decision is made on the technical merit of the bids, but I don't think that is realistic,'' said Charlie Battle, NYC2012's international relations director, who was involved in Atlanta's successful bid for the 1996 Games. ''It is still a political and a personal decision.''
 That is where the bid leaders come in. They know I.O.C. members judge the cities partly on whether they trust the people in charge. So, into the slivers of time the I.O.C. allows contact, the bid leaders try to build relationships with voters, to build that trust.
 Baudillon got a head start on the field, having been part of Paris's bid for the 1992 Games, which went to Barcelona, Spain.
 Coe is known throughout Olympic circles as a champion who has pushed for athletes' involvement in the I.O.C. Among Mayoral's many posts in the Olympic movement, he has been on two Games coordination commissions. Shantsev is the former head of Russia's ice hockey federation.
 Doctoroff is the relative newcomer to I.O.C. circles. It is one of the reasons he turned to Battle for help.
 Doctoroff, 46, not only does the traveling and schmoozing, but he also pays for it. New York's bid, unlike the others, is financed exclusively by private money. Doctoroff pays all of his expenses. He said his BlackBerry bill alone had topped $2,000 a month.
 He juggles this pursuit with being deputy mayor for economic development and rebuilding. (He is also a husband and father of three.) 
 Coe, 48, had to deal with his mother's illness and death, taking over the London bid when it was foundering. He is a husband and father of four, all under 13.
 ''I told them, 'You won't see a lot of me,''' Coe said. ''They said, 'It's O.K., because we want the Games.' It's the first job I've had that they really understand.''
 Those are the kinds of stories the bid leaders share. They are among the few people who can understand the demands of their jobs. So when they see each other at I.O.C. gatherings, they often go out to dinner. By all accounts, they put aside their rivalry.
 ''We've actually developed nice relationships that I hope will survive this process,'' Doctoroff said. ''There is a shared experience. We always have a good time when we get together.''
 Empathy, after all, is a valuable thing.

HEADLINE: Bowling for Democracy

BYLINE: By Orlando Patterson and Jason Kaufman. 
Orlando Patterson is a professor of sociology and Jason Kaufman is an associate professor of sociology at Harvard. Their paper on cricket appears in the next issue of The American Sociological Review.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. 

 BODY:
CRICKET, the quintessential English game, is nonetheless one of the most international of sports. It is a dominant game in more countries than any other sport except soccer, in lands as varied as Australia, India, Pakistan, South Africa and the Commonwealth Caribbean. But a glance at the global map of cricket poses a remarkable cultural puzzle.
 Why, on the one hand, does the game flourish in lands like Pakistan and India, where a hard-fought series can transfix two nations and even lead to improved diplomatic relations? (Last month's series, in which Pakistan defeated India by 159 runs, concluded with a historic meeting between Pakistan's president and India's prime minister.) And why, on the other hand, is cricket not much played in other former British colonies like Canada -- or, for that matter, in the United States, with its heritage and ''special relationship'' with Britain? 
 The puzzle only deepens when one considers that cricket was once popular in both Canada and the United States. It rivaled baseball for most of the 19th century, with as many stories in the sports pages of The New York Times until 1880. Indeed, the world's first international test match was played between Canada and the United States in 1844. So the puzzle is not so much why it was never adopted in North America, but why in the early 20th century it was subsequently rejected.
 Many popular explanations are flawed. Climate has nothing to do with it; cricket emerged as a summer game, and is easily played in North America during mild weather. North American multiculturalism is hardly a factor, given the game's popularity in the multicultural societies of the Caribbean and South Africa. Ethnicity cannot be the answer: while the Scots, with their preference for curling, predominated among early Canadian immigrants, there was a far greater proportion of English in North America than in India or the Caribbean; meanwhile, the preponderance of the Irish in Australia did not prevent cricket from becoming that country's national pastime. Why is it, then, that hockey and baseball eventually trumped cricket in Canada and the United States?
 The most common argument is that cricket was too long and slow for fast-paced North America; formal test matches last for five days. This explanation at least has some merit -- though not in the manner usually understood.
 Cricket lost ground in North America because of the egalitarian ethos of its societies. Rich Americans and Canadians had constant anxiety about their elite status, which prompted them to seek ways to differentiate themselves from the masses. One of those ways was cricket, which was cordoned off as an elites-only pastime, a sport only for those wealthy enough to belong to expensive cricket clubs committed to Victorian ideals of sportsmanship. In late 19th-century Canada, according to one historian, ''the game became associated more and more with an older and more old-fashioned Anglo-Saxon elite.''
 This elite appropriation played into the hands of baseball entrepreneurs who actively worked to diminish cricket's popularity. A.G. Spalding, described in the Baseball Hall of Fame as the ''organizational genius of baseball's pioneer days,'' was typical. ''I have declared cricket is a genteel game,'' he mocked in ''America's National Game,'' his 1911 best seller. ''It is. Our British cricketer, having finished his day's labor at noon, may don his negligee shirt, his white trousers, his gorgeous hosiery and his canvas shoes, and sally forth to the field of sport, with his sweetheart on one arm and his cricket bat under the other, knowing that he may engage in his national pastime without soiling his linen or neglecting his lady.''
 Baseball, in contrast, was sold as a rugged, fast-paced, masculine game, befitting a rugged, fast-paced economic power. Americans of all classes swallowed the chauvinistic line. It was also great business for Spalding. By inventing elaborate baseball gear and paraphernalia, he created a market for his new sporting-goods company.
 In the remaining British colonies, however, the opposite happened. In these rigidly unequal societies the colonial elites and their native allies never had any anxieties about their status, and the British actively promoted the game -- first to native elites, then to the masses.
 In India, the wealthy Parsis first took up the game in emulation of their British masters. Soon, royalty throughout the subcontinent adopted it. English-style grammar schools were an important source of exposure to upwardly mobile native men. In the Caribbean, grammar schools made the imperial game a core feature of their education and made competition possible between different classes and ethnic groups without disrupting the social fabric. As C.L.R. James, the famed Trinidadian intellectual and cricket enthusiast, wrote in his memoir: ''I haven't the slightest doubt that the clash of race, caste and class did not retard but stimulated West Indian cricket.''
 Both colonizer and colonized developed a stake in the popularization of the game. To the British colonists, the ''imperial game'' was the perfect vehicle for civilizing the colonial masses (as it had previously, they imagined, civilized generations of upwardly mobile British schoolboys). For elite members of the colonized, it was a way to curry favor. And for the masses, who quickly mastered the game, it was a symbolically powerful and clandestine form of political liberation as they soon learned to literally beat the British and their native surrogates at their own game.
 The game itself partly facilitated this process. Cricket requires no contact between players, and its strict and complex rules, dress code and officiating largely eliminate any risk of embarrassment in play with those of different ranks or castes. So did the careful allocation of positions; less glamorous roles like bowling and fielding were assigned to social inferiors while those of specialist batsmen and team captain were reserved for elites.
 Much the same was true of 19th-century Australia, at the time a highly stratified colony whose masses were descended from prisoners. Cricket helped antipodean elites cultivate their Englishness, but the size and isolation of their European settlements limited the extent to which they could be truly exclusive. North American-style upper-class appropriation of the game was out of the question. Cricket became a powerful unifying force, and prowess at the game, according to one cricket historian, was ''the mark of an amateur gentleman'' from any class.
 As in the Caribbean, cricket was also a major element in the formation of Australian nationalism. The biennial matches with England solidified the link between colony and mother country even as it fostered Australian national pride when the Australians increasingly came to whip the British at their imperial game.
 WHAT broader lessons might the history of cricket have for the globalization of Western cultural practices? It shows that such practices can be promoted or discouraged from the top down; it is not necessarily a bottom-up process, as is commonly believed. Nor does such downward dissemination require the point of a gun. The passion for cricket in places like Pakistan and India also shows that a complex Western cultural practice can be adopted in its entirety by very different cultures, even when highly identified with its country of origin. 
 Might the same be true of other Western cultural practices, like democracy?
