HEADLINE: Dead Presidents

BYLINE: By Bruce Handy. 
Bruce Handy, a frequent contributor to the Book Review, is a senior articles editor and writer at Vanity Fair.

 BODY:

ASSASSINATION VACATION
By Sarah Vowell.
258 pp. Simon & Schuster. $21.
 Not long ago, I made the mistake of thinking there was something new-ish under the sun. The occasion was the protracted, nearly concurrent death watches for Terri Schiavo and Pope John Paul II, during which the news media felt compelled to highlight every detail of physical decay, no matter how intimate. Terri Schiavo has just received a morphine suppository! The Pope is being fed through his nose! I don't mean to sound lofty or scornful; I was glued to the tube, too. But for the dying, this gruesome play-by-play seemed a horrible violation, and also a uniquely contemporary one -- yet another symptom of a culture with serious boundary issues.
 Then I read Sarah Vowell's ''Assassination Vacation,'' a learned, engagingly discursive, funny, sometimes even jolly ramble -- literally -- through the landscape of American presidential assassinations. Vowell, a journalist and essayist in the McSweeney's orbit, reminds us that after James A. Garfield was shot in the back on July 2, 1881 (the 20th president was boarding a train in Washington, bound for a New England vacation after only four months in office -- how George W. Bush-like), he lingered on for two and a half months before finally succumbing, and that during this protracted farewell, the citizenry was just as riveted by the president's fluctuating condition as we would be today. Crowds gathered at newspaper and telegraph offices to await the icky medical bulletins emanating from what turned out to be Garfield's deathbed. One day, for instance, the world learned he had had a ''free discharge of healthy-looking pus.'' And after he finally left this mortal coil, the poor man suffered one last invasion of privacy: his spine, removed during autopsy, was passed around to jurors during the trial of his assassin, a delusional man who had been haunting the White House and the State Department in hopes of being named ambassador to France. To what evidentiary purpose Garfield's spine ended up in jurors' hands, Vowell does not say -- even in death, most politicians would be mortified to have their backbones examined -- but the incident does serve as proof that when it comes to ghoulishness, you'll rarely outdo the 19th century, and this despite its lack of 24-hour cable news networks and their attendant programming needs.
 ''Assassination Vacation'' revels in such small epiphanies. Having made the commercially courageous decision to avoid the catnip that is the Kennedy name, Vowell restricts her gaze to America's first three presidential murders: those of Abraham Lincoln, Garfield and William McKinley. Mixing travelogue, history, personal essay and social criticism, she follows the loose formula perfected in two previous collections of magazine pieces and adapted versions of her appearances on public radio's ''This American Life,'' where she is a regular. (She has entertained an even larger audience as the voice of Violet, the sulky teenage daughter in ''The Incredibles.'')
 Here, displaying heroic obsessiveness, she dedicates herself to visiting virtually every historical site associated with the three assassinations no matter how tangential, roaming as far afield as the Dry Tortugas, 70 miles off Key West, where four of the conspirators in Lincoln's shooting were locked up. And then it's off to Mount Marcy in the Adirondacks, which is where, in 1901, Vice President Theodore Roosevelt had been enjoying a ''bully good tramp'' through the woods when he learned that McKinley, gut-shot by a gloomy anarchist, was near death and that he, Roosevelt, would soon be president. Never at a loss for a bus ticket or a friend willing to drive her to a weed-choked cemetery, Vowell shows herself to be a connoisseur of half-hidden historical plaques, recreated sitting rooms and docents in hoop skirts. She suffers for her quest. ''Going to Ford's Theater to watch the play,'' she notes, ''is like going to Hooters for the food.''
 Vowell attributes what she calls ''this whole morbid assassination death trip'' to, in part, her anger at the current president and his policies, particularly the war in Iraq -- to which she draws a parallel with McKinley's elective attack on Spain. (This isn't just a lefty reflex: Karl Rove is also said to be fond of McKinley-Bush parallels.) Her ''simmering rage'' at the president alarms her: 
 ''If I can summon this much bitterness toward a presidential human being, I can sort of, kind of see how this amount of bile or more, teaming up with disappointment, unemployment, delusions of grandeur and mental illness, could prompt a crazier narcissistic creep to buy one of this country's widely available handguns. Not that I, I repeat, condone that. Like Lincoln, I would like to believe the ballot is stronger than the bullet. Then again, he said that before he got shot.'' 
 Readers who aren't offended by the preceding passage will find much to engage them. Vowell makes an excellent traveling companion, what with her rare combination of erudition and cheek. Structurally peripatetic, ''Assassination Vacation'' is like a real vacation in that its lack of a rigorous itinerary, its willingness to wander hither and yon as Vowell's interest is piqued, can be refreshing -- if you are not the sort of person who absolutely insists on arriving at the B & B in time for the lovely tea service. As you may have guessed, this book is an often astounding compendium of forgotten history and trivia, to the extent that those are two different things. We learn, for instance, that the canny thespian John Wilkes Booth, stalking Lincoln that fateful April evening at Ford's Theater, waited for a surefire laugh line to cover his shot; and that the line, a rejoinder in which a female character is dismissed as a ''sockdologizing old man trap,'' hasn't aged all that well. Still, as Vowell writes, ''it is a comfort of sorts to know that the bullet hit Lincoln mid-guffaw. . . . At least his last conscious moment was a hoot.'' 
 At some point, though, you do crave a little traction where the wheels hit the road. For all its larkiness, ''Assassination Vacation'' means to be a serious book about a troublesome subject. It is a serious book, although I'm not sure what Vowell is ultimately trying to say. I'm not sure she knows, either; she tacitly admits as much by avoiding conclusions as if they themselves were gloomy anarchists or lunatic ambassadors manques, although she does draw one interesting comparison:
 ''The egomania required to be president or a presidential assassin makes the two types brothers of sorts. Presidents and presidential assassins are like Las Vegas and Salt Lake City that way. Even though one city is all about sin and the other is all about salvation, they are identical, one-dimensional company towns built up out of the desert by the sheer will of true believers. The assassins and the presidents invite the same basic question: Just who do you think you are?''
 Vowell seems to consider this a rhetorical question, and perhaps rightly so. Assassination, as a subject, may seem like one of those perfect, irresistible windows on the American psyche, like baseball, or the mob or Marilyn Monroe. But when you look more closely, assassins themselves may be too ornery and too peculiar, their motives too singular, their moments in history too specific to serve as useful dots for connection -- a moral you could also draw from Stephen Sondheim's struggles with the fascinating, equally larky, but ultimately incoherent musical ''Assassins,'' another take on this same sorry subject. Vowell, for her part, pretty much throws up her hands when it comes to Larger Meaning and heads for the next historical marker. Not to sound like Deepak Chopra or Mitch Albom, but it's best to read this book for the journey, not the destination.

HEADLINE: McEurope

BYLINE: By Johann Hari. 
Johann Hari is a columnist for The Independent in London and the author of ''God Save the Queen? Monarchy and the Truth About the Windsors.''

 BODY:

IRRESISTIBLE EMPIRE
America's Advance Through Twentieth-Century Europe.
By Victoria de Grazia.
Illustrated. 586 pp. The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $29.95.
 Victoria De Grazia slaps Europeans in the face with her title: face it, mes amis, you are part of the American empire. Zut alors! As a proud European, I confess to letting out a small splutter. Didn't we just snub the emperor-president, George W. Bush, by rejecting great swaths of his foreign policy? Don't we have a social democratic model that avoids the vertiginous inequalities of the United States? Aren't we free and self-determining democracies, building up our own superpower based in Brussels? 
 Well, maybe -- but if Charlemagne or Napoleon could see their continent today, they would be with de Grazia. One glance at Europe's great capitals, and they would assume Europe had been conquered, occupied and settled by Americans. The men who dreamed of l'Europe profonde would curse the ubiquity of Eminem as they sat in the greasy KFC on the Falls Road in Belfast munching their Chicken Popcorn. They would stagger their way around Italy's most beautiful city, guided by a McDonald's map of McVenice. 
 ''Irresistible Empire'' is the story of how this happened, of how an imperium came to Europe in the form of an emporium. Unlike the Middle East and Latin America, Europe has seen only the peaceful face of America's empire. De Grazia, a professor of history at Columbia University, shows how -- in just one century -- the Old Continent was subject to slow conquest by a million consumer goods. 
 She talks us through the rise of a string of outwardly banal institutions: Rotary Clubs, supermarkets, the Hollywood star system, corporate advertising. With the careful skill of an expert defusing an explosive, she teases out the dense clusters of political ideology embodied in these seemingly everyday social institutions. 
 The old European capitalism was epitomized by the small neighborhood store. At its core was ''a commercial ethic that still sought trust in the longevity of contacts and the solidarity of face-to-face contacts.'' Slowly, this model was eclipsed by an American capitalism epitomized by the out-of-town supermarket, big, anonymous and neon. The local, the diverse and the class-segmented were all ironed out in favor of a mass standard of consumption.
 Instead of the Great Man theory of history, de Grazia gives us the Great Bargain theory. It's startling just how rapidly Europe has been changed by this new model. Who knew, for example, that in the late 1950's there was not a single supermarket in Milan, and this was by no means untypical for a European city? How many of us realize that as recently as 1954, only 9 percent of French people had a refrigerator? Yet in a work crammed with exhaustive research, the reader pines for analysis. All of contemporary European politics spins on the question: Were the developments de Grazia details good for Europe? 
 The answer cannot be squeezed into the simple-minded good-and-evil story craved on both sides of the Atlantic. De Grazia concentrates primarily on the areas where Americanization has had a broadly positive effect. But even the Marxist theorist Antonio Gramsci wrote lovingly in his ''Prison Notebooks'' of how Americanism and Fordism were hollowing out the old feudal snobberies.
 Perhaps unwittingly, de Grazia steers away from the areas where corporate Americanization has been pernicious for Europe. I would like to see her turn her remarkable skills to charting the effect of American corporate buyouts on Europe's news and entertainment media. Nor does she mention the environmental impact of this economic system. And is any analysis of European supermarkets complete without mentioning the biggest public health scare on the continent for 50 years? The supermarkets, relentless pressure for cheap food and industrial agriculture all pushed farmers to feed processed meat to cattle -- thus leading to Mad Cow disease.
 The other gap in de Grazia's narrative concerns a strange historical irony: Americanization gave birth to the idea of Europe. ''Henry Ford was as much a father of the European idea as anyone from Europe, given his company's pioneering effort to treat the European region as a single sales territory,'' she notes dryly. She's right, but the point is left hanging. Ford set in motion the conflict that will define the European Union over the coming decades. It can be summarized in a simple question: Does Europe exist to achieve Ford's goal -- one vast market for American goods -- or to resist this possibility and create a distinctively social democratic alternative?
 De Grazia focuses on one relatively minor European-resistance cause -- the slow food movement -- and at first it seems an eccentric choice. Founded in the late 1980's, it has a simple purpose: to give everybody the time and space to eat good, unprocessed food slowly and carefully. When America waves a Big Mac, the Slow Foodies want Europe to wave a bowl of freshly cooked pasta al dente. But if they are few in number, their approach symbolizes the wider European reaction to American neoliberalism: slow down. Europeans want long vacations, generous welfare states and flexible work hours. They -- we -- are trying to articulate a different model of consumerism that values leisure and family as much as work, work, work. Can this work? Is there a way to combine America's dazzling consumer economy with social justice and environmental sanity? 
 Like many Europeans, I have a dystopian vision of the death of Europe as an alternative to America. Far from resolving tensions across the Atlantic, the irresistible empire's blanding out would simply produce a long European grudge, a quiet rage that we had sold our identity for a bag of Doritos. I see it now: Napoleon and Charlemagne sit grumbling in a doughnut shop after a long day in the new Euro-America. Napoleon swallows hard on a Krispy Kreme, turns to a weeping Charlemagne, and whispers, ''Dude, I so hate America.''

HEADLINE: Smart? Fine, but Do You Know What to Do With the Olive Pits?

BYLINE: By EILENE ZIMMERMAN

 BODY:
At the annual senior etiquette dinner at Salve Regina University in Newport, R.I., in February, one student, Jennifer Bladykas, was surprised to learn that reaching for the salt before tasting her entree tells people she is prone to rash decisions. She also learned where to put the spoon after stirring her coffee, and in what direction to pass bread. 
 ''Dining out seemed so simple, but I realize now it says a lot about your character,'' said Ms. Bladykas, a Long Island native who will begin a job with a New York City marketing firm after graduation. 
 Courtney Richardson, a senior at Lehman College in the Bronx, now knows that if the host orders a salad but he wants steak, he's eating salad, too. And after attending a March session of Goofs, Goblets and Getting the Edge, a program at Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., Brandon Lee, a junior, sees the wisdom of doing without leftovers. ''I probably would have said yes to the doggie bag,'' Mr. Lee said. ''But they told us never to do that. It's not the Last Supper; it's business.'' 
 It used to be that college seniors and graduate students prepared for the work world with just the usual round of workshops on resume writing and interview skills. But as this generation prepares for life after college, they are also flocking to seminars on dining etiquette, an offering on the rise at colleges and universities nationwide, to learn the fine points of dealing with olive pits and missing dessert forks.
 Philip Gardner, an economist at Michigan State University who studies college labor market trends as director of the Collegiate Employment Research Institute, said students were doing much more than they used to in preparation for the work world. ''The job market is still very competitive,'' he said, ''and there is a lot of experienced labor out there also looking for work.'' 
 At Marist College, the waiting list for the twice-a-semester dining etiquette program is hundreds of students long; the Dining for Success program at the State University of New York in Binghamton was so popular last fall that it had to be moved to a bigger hall. 
 Etiquette consultants say business is booming. ''I started doing Girl Scout troops and PTA trainings in the late 1990's, but my business has increased 100 percent since 2000,'' said Maureen Wild Sanders, founder of High Road Solutions, a business protocol training firm in Bridgewater, N.J. ''Now 75 percent of my clients are in higher education or corporations.'' 
 Although good manners have always been important in business, etiquette specialists say its importance lapsed in the heady days of the late 90's. 
 ''You had these young entrepreneurs wearing sandals and a T-shirt to work, and that spilled over into blue-chip corporations, who questioned their buttoned-up culture,'' said Pamela J. Holland, co-author of ''Help! Was That a Career Limiting Move?'' (Career Skills Press, 2001) and chief operating officer of Brody Communications in Philadelphia, which provides dining etiquette training to corporate clients. ''I think this renewed interest in civility and manners is a reaction to that.'' 
 The lack of formal dining knowledge seems especially acute in Generation Y -- generally considered anyone born after 1980. James Chung, president of Research Advisors in Boston, a strategy and research firm that focuses on generational demographics and shifts in social attitudes, says this generation has grown up during a fundamental shift in American family structure and a move away from formality in culture generally. 
 ''This was a very mobile generation of kids -- they spawned ubiquitous eat-on-the-run products and supersize drinks that fit into minivan cup holders -- and they lost the habit of valuing and respecting family dining time,'' Mr. Chung said. 
 Of course, a business meal is not a family dinner, and keeping elbows off the table will not be enough to impress a potential employer. Students at college etiquette seminars are usually asked to completely rethink the way they view a meal. 
 Ann Marie Sabath, founder of At Ease, a Midtown Manhattan etiquette training firm, and author of ''Business Etiquette: 101 Ways to Conduct Business With Charm & Savvy'' (Career Press, 2002), conducted the dining etiquette program at Lehman College in April. She tried to impress on students that business meals ''aren't really about eating.'' 
 ''These kids don't realize that dinner or lunch is an interview; the food is just an excuse for getting together. We teach them everything from what to order to how to eat -- no cutting up all the food beforehand, no chewing on the ice when the drink is done.'' 
 At Marist College, etiquette training includes a multicourse dinner of challenging foods, like salads with cherry tomatoes and olives with pits, French onion soup and pasta with red sauce. 
 SUNY Binghamton began its dining etiquette program in 2003 in response to feedback from employers and alumni that its students were ''smart but needed to strengthen their savvy and social skills,'' said Nancy Paul, director of the school's career development center.. 
 Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., holds a four-course dining etiquette workshop each spring, and Richard L. White, director of career services, said he was surprised at the general level of naivete.
 ''Students ask things like what to do with food stuck in your teeth, what to do if you spill something, drop your fork, don't like your food,'' he said. ''They are also very concerned about making conversation during meals. This generation lives on the Internet and simply doesn't know how to make social chit-chat.''
 Although it is Generation Y entering the work force, their predecessors in Generation X -- now aged 26 to 40 -- are often in middle and even senior management, and companies increasingly call on consultants like Ms. Sabath to help them brush up on etiquette skills. Ms. Sabath said 60 percent of her clients were corporations wanting to make sure employees did not embarrass themselves or the company when conducting business socially. 
 Pauline Winick and Dale Webb, founders of the Protocol Center in Miami, said corporations were about the same percentage of their clients. ''We are often asked to train midlevel employees,'' Ms. Winick said, ''because the company can't send them to work with a client until they know their level of social skill.'' 
 Regardless of one's place in the work hierarchy, it is hard to argue against good manners, said Ms. Wild Sanders. ''If you are competing for a job or promotion against others with the same level of competency but you have the social skills, too,'' she said, ''you always clobber the competition.''

HEADLINE: Stony Brook Wins Battle Over Property

BYLINE: By BARBARA GERBASI

 BODY:
AFTER almost three years of conflicting visions and stalemated negotiations, the Gyrodyne property, a bucolic strip of land bordering a stretch of Route 25A in St. James, will become part of a research and development center at Stony Brook University. 
 The Gyrodyne Company of America, which has owned the property since 1951 and built pilotless helicopters there until 1973, had hoped to build a luxury golf community with 80 town houses and 256 houses. 
 The university wanted to build a research and development campus and, after fruitless negotiations, began efforts last year to acquire the largely undeveloped tract through condemnation proceedings. 
 A four-judge panel of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled on April 25 that Stony Brook could proceed with its plans to annex 246 acres of the 314-acre Gyrodyne property and build its research and development campus. The tract, which is next to the university, is also known as Flowerfield.
 Work on the first building, which will house the Center for Excellence in Wireless Technology, is expected to start early next year. It will be financed through Gov. George E. Pataki's Statewide Center for Excellence Initiative; $50 million was allocated for the project, which straddles Brookhaven and Smithtown.University officials said that 133 other major research universities in the United States had research-and-development parks and that the absence of one at Stony Brook would limit its ability to stimulate the Long Island economy if young scientists and entrepreneurs left for opportunities elsewhere. 
 John Jay LaValle, Brookhaven's town supervisor, called the court's ruling a crucial decision for the future of Long Island's economy. 
 ''The development of these research centers will spin off new technologies and high-paying jobs to the Long Island economy,'' he said. 
 Not everyone is as enthusiastic about the project. 
 ''A planner looks at this project from another perspective,'' said Frank DeRubeis, the director of planning for the Town of Smithtown. ''They are proposing something that is reasonably low key, but who knows what may happen in the long run? The plan could change. They are not bound to it. 
 ''Right now the primary access to the new part of campus will be through Nicholls Road, which could accommodate the extra traffic. However, if they were to change access to Route 25A, a road that is already operating at capacity, it would be a problem.''
 Peter Pitsiokos, the executive vice president of Gyrodyne, took a wait-and-see approach, too.
 ''It remains to be seen if the state does indeed have the money to purchase the land at the fair market value,'' he said, adding that it could be as much as $100 million.
 Gyrodyne has no plans to appeal the court's ruling. ''They didn't leave us any hope,'' Mr. Pitsiokos said.
 The company will continue to own 68 acres at the site and to lease its industrial park there, with 70 tenants. 
 The university's plans call for 100,000 square feet of offices and research laboratories in the first phase of the project in a three-story brick and metal-panel building. 
 Patrick Calabria, a university spokesman, said that the labs would support highly specialized electronics and research programs focusing on wireless devices and communications, networking and software systems, especially cybersecurity. 
 This first building is scheduled to be followed by nine others over 10 years. The plan suggests that part of the space could be occupied by businesses that team up with the university in corporate research and product development.
 The 246 acres are undeveloped and will require no change from the current zoning, light industrial.
 These are the nine other buildings: 
 The recent state budget provides $22.2 million for a Center for Computational Neuroscience. 
 The Nanoscience and Technology Research Center will be a 75,000-square-foot lab building that would combine physical- and life-science research and engineering. 
 The Development Partners Research Center would develop practical applications for discoveries made on campus.
 The Development Facility will be a proving ground for emerging technologies.
 The Software Incubator Facility will have 50,000 square feet for software development. 
 The High-Tech Competitiveness Institute will house a research center to help established industries eliminate waste. 
 Three other research-and-development buildings similar to the Development Partners Research Center are also planned. 
 ''The cost of any future buildings will be financed in a variety of ways, either through capital budgets or through partnerships with private industry, who would like to take advantage of the research and intellectual capital,'' Mr. Calabria said.

HEADLINE: Four Months of Fridays

BYLINE: By David Kehr, compiled with the assistance of Suzanne O'Connor.

 BODY:
All dates are subject to change.
 Friday
 CRAZY LIKE A FOX
 Roger Rees stars as a Virginia blueblood who finds that his family estate has been taken over -- with the papers to prove it -- by a pair of cunning outsiders (Paul Fitzgerald and Christina Rouner). Mary McDonnell co-stars in a film directed by Richard Squires, his first.
KICKING AND SCREAMING
 Will Ferrell finds he has a lot of psychological baggage to unpack when the children's soccer team he coaches ends up in a tight contest with a team led by his fiercely competitive father (Robert Duvall). Jesse Dylan (''How High'') directs. 
 KINGS AND QUEEN
 Arnaud Desplechin, one of France's most gifted younger filmmakers, delivers a psychologically insightful story of a schizophrenic (Mathieu Almaric) and the controlling single mother (Emmanuelle Devos) to whom he was once married.
 LAYER CAKE
 More of those lovable British gangster lads from Matthew Vaughn, the producer of ''Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels'' and ''Snatch,'' now turned director. Daniel Craig (''Sylvia,'' ''The Mother'') plays a high-level cocaine dealer who wants to weasel out of the business; his boss, Michael Gambon, won't let him.
 MAD HOT BALLROOM
 A group of New York City schoolchildren abandon rap for ballroom dancing, becoming what the press notes call ''ladies and gentlemen'' along the way. A documentary directed by Marilyn Agrelo.
 MA MERE
 Christophe Honore (''Seventeen Times Camille Cassard,'' 2002) adapts a novel by Georges Bataille about a woman (Isabelle Huppert) who takes charge of the sexual education of her repressed son (Louis Garrel from ''The Dreamers''). With Emma de Caunes.
 MINDHUNTERS
 The F.B.I.'s top psychological profilers gather on a remote island for a training exercise, only to find that one of their number is a rampaging serial killer. Sounds like the latest variation on the Agatha Christie chestnut ''Ten Little Indians.'' Renny Harlin directed; with Christian Slater, Val Kilmer and Jonny Lee Miller.
 MONSTER-IN-LAW
 Is it safe for Jennifer Lopez to show her, uh, face again? Here she is in a long-gestating comedy about a professional dog walker who meets her ideal man (Michael Vartan) but has to cope with his domineering mother (Jane Fonda, in her first film since ''Stanley and Iris in 1990). Wanda Sykes lends support. Robert Luketic (''Legally Blonde'') directs.
 UNLEASHED
 The martial arts star Jet Li returns in a movie produced by the French action auteur Luc Besson (''The Fifth Element''), who is also the screenplay's co-author. Mr. Li plays an Asian orphan who has been raised by his Scottish guardian (Bob Hoskins) as a human pit bull. Between bloody matches in underground sites, he discovers that there's another side to life, thanks to a blind piano tuner (Morgan Freeman). Louis Leterrier directed this big-budget French production (with dialogue, of course, in English).
 May 18
 MOJADOS: THROUGH THE NIGHT
 The filmmaker Tommy Davis accompanies four men from Michoacan, Mexico, as they try to cross the border into the United States.
 SHAKE HANDS WITH THE DEVIL
 The genocide in Rwanda, as experienced and recalled by a Canadian Army general, Romeo Dallaire, who was the head of the United Nations peacekeeping mission. The director, Peter Raymont, accompanies General Dallaire as he returns to the region and takes stock of his accomplishments and failures.
 May 19
 STAR WARS EPISODE III: REVENGE OF THE SITH
 George Lucas closes out the second ''Star Wars'' trilogy (though by the story, it's the first), as Anakin Skywalker (Hayden Christensen) drifts toward the Dark Side, and Obi-Wan (Ewan McGregor) becomes nervous. Meanwhile, Padme (Natalie Portman) is harboring the historic zygotes that will become Luke Skywalker and Princess Leia. With Ian McDiarmid, Samuel L. Jackson, Jimmy Smits, Frank Oz and Christopher Lee; Mr. Lucas directed. A related article is on Page 30.
 May 20
 DOMINION: PREQUEL TO THE EXORCIST
 Paul Schrader's thoughtful, restrained version of ''Exorcist: The Beginning'' was initially rejected by its producers as not scary enough and then remade in its entirety by Renny Harlin. But when Mr. Harlin's version flopped at the box office last summer, the producers, Morgan Creek Productions, decided to release Mr. Schrader's interpretation of the material as well. Stellan Skarsgard plays the young Father Merrin (Max von Sydow in the 1973 original), experiencing his first encounter with his diabolical nemesis in the deserts of West Africa.
 SECOND BEST
 A failed publishing executive (Joe Pantoliano) and his best friend from childhood, now a successful movie producer (Boyd Gaines), compete for the attentions of the same woman (Jennifer Tilly). Eric Weber wrote and directed.
 SEX, POLITICS AND COCKTAILS
 Julien Hernandez directed and stars in this comedy about a 30-year-old filmmaker whose search for a soul mate leads him to some surprising discoveries about his sexuality.
 TELL THEM WHO YOU ARE
 The filmmaker Mark Wexler examines his relationship with his father, the cinematographer Haskell Wexler. With appearances by Billy Crystal, Michael Douglas, Jane Fonda, Milos Forman and Norman Jewison.
 May 25
 THE FEARLESS FREAKS
 Highlights from the 20-year history of the Oklahoma City art-rock band called the Flaming Lips. Brad Beesley directs.
 May 27
 BOMB THE SYSTEM
 Mark Webber plays a young New York graffiti artist (aka, urban vandal) who's torn between tagging as a career and going to college. Adam Bhala Lough directed.
 A LEAGUE OF ORDINARY GENTLEMEN
 Christopher Browne's documentary charts the efforts of a newly installed chief executive, Steve Miller, to ''modernize'' the Professional Bowlers' Association. He meets his match in an old pro, Pete Weber, who has no intention of being brought up to date. Judging by the photos, mullets abound.
 THE LONGEST YARD
 A former star quarterback now serving a prison term is forced by a sadistic warden to field and train a team of inmates to take on the brutal prison guards in their annual game. Adam Sandler takes over the Burt Reynolds role in this remake of Robert Aldrich's 1974 film, though Mr. Reynolds is still on board, as a former college coach who helps out Mr. Sandler. With Chris Rock, William Fichtner, James Cromwell and Cloris Leachman; Peter Segal (''50 First Dates'') directs.
 MADAGASCAR
 The new computer-animated cartoon from DreamWorks centers on four animal buddies from the Central Park Zoo -- a preening lion (with the voice of Ben Stiller), a wisecracking zebra (Chris Rock), a sensible hippo (Jada Pinkett Smith) and a neurotic giraffe (David Schwimmer) -- who find themselves washed ashore on the island of Madagascar, a less controlled environment than they're accustomed to. Directed by Eric Darnell and Tom McGrath.
 THE NINTH DAY
 A dissident Roman Catholic priest (Ulrich Matthes) is released from Dachau and sent home to occupied Luxembourg, where he is expected to convert the bishop to the Nazi cause. August Diehl plays the Gestapo chief who accompanies him. Directed by Volker Schlondorff.
 PURE
 Paul (Harry Eden), a 10-year-old, enlists the help of a friendly waitress (Keira Knightley) to help his mother (Molly Parker) kick her heroin addiction. Gillies MacKinnon (''Hideous Kinky'') directed this British feature from 2002.
 SAVING FACE
 A middle-aged Asian woman (Joan Chen) becomes unexpectedly pregnant and moves in with her lesbian daughter (Michelle Krusiec) to have her baby. Alice Wu's film, her first, was an official selection at Sundance this year.
 A WAKE IN PROVIDENCE
 Filmed in 1999, Rosario Roveto Jr.'s independent film is a comedy about an Italian-American who takes his African-American fiancee to his grandfather's funeral. Vincent Pagano and Victoria Rowell star.
 June
 June 1
 OR -- MY TREASURE
 The winner of the best first-feature award at the 2004 Cannes Film Festival, Keren Yedaya's Israeli film follows the torturous relationship of a prostitute (Ronit Elkabetz) and her daughter (Dana Ivgy).
 THE SISTERHOOD OF THE TRAVELING PANTS
 Four teenage girlfriends pass a favorite pair of blue jeans among themselves as a way of staying in touch over the summer. Ken Kwapis directed from the best-selling tweener novel by Ann Brashares; with Amber Tamblyn, America Ferrera, Blake Lively and Alexis Bledel.
 WHITE DIAMOND
 The filmmaker Werner Herzog accompanies the aeronautics expert Graham Dorrington on a balloon trip into the heart of the Guyana. A related article is on Page 13.
 June 3
 APRES VOUS
 A happy-go-lucky headwaiter at a Paris restaurant (Daniel Auteuil) tries to help a depressed friend (Jose Garcia) get back together with his ex-girlfriend (Sandrine Kiberlain) but ends up falling for her himself. Pierre Salvadori directs.
 CATERINA IN THE CITY
 Italy's reigning soulful hunk, Sergio Castellitto, plays a teacher who moves from a small town to Rome with his reluctant daughter in tow. She soon finds herself caught up in a conflict of cliques (vide, ''Mean Girls'') at her new high school. Paolo Virzi directed.
 CINDERELLA MAN
 Jim Braddock (Russell Crowe), an aging, unemployed dockworker, makes an unexpected comeback as a boxer and, as Depression-era America cheers him on, faces the deadly heavyweight champion Max Baer (Craig Bierko). Renee Zellweger co-stars as Braddock's infinitely supportive wife; Paul Giamatti is his tough-talking trainer. An inspirational tale about a boxer? Sounds like an Oscar contender, except for one, small hitch, otherwise known as ''Million Dollar Baby.'' Ron Howard directs. A related article is on Page 3.
 THE DEAL
 An investment banker (Christian Slater) and his top assistant (Selma Blair) attempt to engineer the takeover of a Russian oil company but soon discover that all is not as it seems. Harvey Kahn directed; with John Heard and Angie Harmon.
 DEEP BLUE
 Michael Gambon narrates a documentary about the ocean depths, directed by Andy Byatt and Alastair Fothergill.
 HIGH TENSION
 Alexandre Aja's 2003 French film has already earned a cult reputation as an unusually effective slasher film, though the setup doesn't sound all that original: two university students (Cecile De France and Maiwenn Le Besco) repair to a house in the country for a weekend of cramming, but then comes an unexpected knock at the door Also known as ''Switchblade Romance.''
 LORDS OF DOGTOWN
 A gang of Venice Beach surfers called the Z-Boys are among the first to discover the possibilities of the new skateboard technology of the 1970's but then have trouble handling fame when it arrives. Written by Stacy Peralta, who wrote and directed the documentary ''Dogtown and Z-Boys.'' Catherine Hardwicke (''Thirteen'') directs a cast that includes Emile Hirsch, Heath Ledger and Johnny Knoxville.
 MILWAUKEE, MINNESOTA
 After his overprotective mother is killed by a hit-and-run driver, a young fisherman (Troy Garity) must learn to defend himself when two con men go after his mother's life insurance money. Allan Mindel directs.
 ROCK SCHOOL
 Don Argott's documentary examines the real-life version of Richard Linklater's ''School of Rock'' -- a Philadelphia academy called the Paul Green School of Rock Music. The climax comes as some of the students are asked to perform at a Frank Zappa tribute concert abroad.
 June 10
 THE ADVENTURES OF SHARK BOY AND LAVA GIRL
 The prolific Austin, Tex.-based filmmaker Robert Rodriguez (he also has ''Sin City'' in current release) imagines the adventures of a lonely 10-year-old boy (Cayden Boyd) and his two imaginary playmates, Shark Boy (Taylor Lautner) and Lava Girl (Taylor Dooley). David Arquette, Kristen Davis and George Lopez. In 3-D.
 5X2
 A marriage is observed in reverse, from the day of divorce to the day of first meeting, in a new film by France's Francois Ozon (''Swimming Pool''). With Valeria Bruni-Tedeschi and Stephane Freiss.
 HEIGHTS
 Chris Terrio's debut feature follows five characters over the course of a fall day during which they individually face the prospect of changing their lives. With Elizabeth Banks, Glenn Close, Jesse Bradford and John Light. A related article is on Page 15.
 HOWL'S MOVING CASTLE
 Japan's master of hand-drawn animation, Hayao Miyazaki, follows up his brilliant ''Spirited Away'' with an adaptation of a children's novel by Diana Wynne Jones. The dreamlike tale, full of unpredictable transformations and transpositions, centers on a teenage girl turned into an old woman by an evil witch. The Walt Disney Company, in a show of class, will open the film in both subtitled and dubbed versions.
 THE HONEYMOONERS
 An African-American reimagining of Jackie Gleason's classic television series, with Cedric the Entertainer as the bus driver Ralph Kramden and Mike Epps as Ed Norton, his sewer-worker best friend. Together, they hatch some get-rich-quick schemes, while their wives (Gabrielle Union and Regina Hall) offer sarcastic commentary. John Schultz directs.
 MR. AND MRS. SMITH
 The world's two top assassins, Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie, have been so successful at keeping their identities secret that they don't realize they're married to each other. Then comes the inevitable assignment: kill your spouse. Doug Liman directs, in what may or may not be a combination of his rumpled comedy ''Swingers'' and his high-tech thriller ''The Bourne Identity.'' Then again, it sure sounds like ''Prizzi's Honor.''
 SAINT RALPH
 A Roman Catholic high school boy (Adam Butcher) becomes convinced that his mother's life will be miraculously saved if he wins the Boston Marathon, and turns to a priest (Campbell Scott) for physical and spiritual training. Michael McGowan wrote and directed.
 SEQUINS
 A first film from France, about the bond that develops between a woman (Ariane Ascaride) who has recently lost her son in a motorcycle accident and a pregnant teenager (Lola Neymark) to whom the older woman teaches the fine art of embroidery. By Eleonore Faucher, fresh from the New Directors/New Films Festival.
 WILD SIDE
 Sebastien Lifshitz's French feature imagines a menage a trois among Sylvie, a transsexual prostitute; Jamel, a North African hustler; and Mikhail, a Russian illegal immigrant.
 June 15
 BATMAN BEGINS
 Warner Brothers tries to revive the Batman franchise, dormant since ''Batman and Robin'' in 1997, by applying less camp and more doom by means of its director, Christopher Nolan of the noir thriller ''Memento.'' Christian Bale is the brooding hero; Michael Caine is his loyal retainer Alfred; and Liam Neeson, Morgan Freeman, Ken Watanabe, Katie Homes and Tom Wilkinson fill out the impressive cast. A related article is on Page 1.
 WHEEL OF TIME
 The German filmmaker Werner Herzog, who seems to be clearing his shelves this season, offers a personal perspective on Buddhism. A related article is on Page 13.
 June 17
 DORIAN BLUES
 A misfit teenager (Michael McMillian) living in a conservative Upstate New York town, begins to suspect that he may be gay. N.Y.U. and Greenwich Village promise liberation. Written and directed by Tennyson Bardwell.
 GOD'S SANDBOX
 The love affair between a Western tourist and a Bedouin sheik comes to a tragic end when the woman is expected to submit to an ancient tribal ritual. An Israeli film, directed by Doron Eran.
 THE GREAT WATER
 An orphan is sent to a brutal re-education camp in the early, pro-Stalin years of the postwar Yugoslav government. From Macedonia; Ivo Trajkov directs.
 MY SUMMER OF LOVE
 The intense relationship between two young women in the English countryside, one an edgy outsider (Natalie Press), the other wealthy and sophisticated (Emily Blunt). Directed by Pawel Pawlikowski, whose 2000 ''Last Resort'' was a fine study in social realism. A related article is on Page 15.
 THE PERFECT MAN
 Hilary Duff as a teenager who uses the Internet to concoct an imaginary admirer for her romantically challenged mother (Heather Locklear). When Mom wants to meet him, Ms. Duff drafts her best friend's dashing uncle (Chris Noth). Tweener fodder from the director Mark Rosman (''A Cinderella Story'') and the writer Gina Wendkos (''The Princess Diaries'').
 June 24
 BEWITCHED
 Following ''The Honeymooners,'' this is Paramount's second film this month based on an old television show. But the director and co-writer, Nora Ephron, has apparently given the concept a Pirandellian twist: it's now about a slipping movie star (Will Ferrell) who's cast as Darrin in a remake of the old sitcom. Allowed to choose his leading lady, he picks a nonprofessional (Nicole Kidman), who happens to be a real witch. Zaniness ensues, as Shirley MacLaine, Michael Caine, Jason Schwartzman look on. A related article is on Page 3.
 THE DUKES OF HAZZARD
 Jay Chandrasekhar of the comedy troupe Broken Lizard (''Super Troopers'') was hired to direct this reinterpretation of the 1979-85 show about fast cars and slow sheriffs, which suggests that the film may not be taking a totally reverent approach to the material. Seann William Scott and Johnny Knoxville play the two fun-loving Duke brothers; Jessica Simpson is Daisy, in her first film appearance in a role other than ''herself.'' And Burt Reynolds, the patron saint of the genre, appears as the Dukes' sworn enemy, Boss Hogg. The big question: Will they still have that Confederate flag decal on their car?
 HERBIE: FULLY LOADED
 Not a studio to leave a property unexploited, Disney here revives its series of children's films about a lovable thinking Volkswagen. America's hard-partying sweetheart, Lindsay Lohan, plays Herbie's new owner, who's determined to enter the tail-wagging vehicle in a Nascar race in order to save her house. With Matt Dillon and Michael Keaton; the director, a Sundance alumna, is Angela Robinson (''D.E.B.S.'').
 LAND OF THE DEAD
 George A. Romero returns to the horror subgenre he created with ''Night of the Living Dead'' in 1968. This will be Mr. Romero's fourth episode in the ''Living Dead'' series, set this time in a city that has been fortified against the hungry zombie hordes lurching around the countryside. But as complacency builds within the city, the zombies are slowly organizing themselves into an army outside. With Simon Baker, John Leguizamo, Dennis Hopper and Asia Argento.
 MARCH OF THE PENGUINS
 Luc Jacquet's nature documentary follows a pair of emperor penguins as they make their annual pilgrimage across Antarctica.
 ME AND YOU AND EVERYONE WE KNOW
 Miranda July's feature, her first as writer and director, won a special prize from this year's Sundance jury for ''originality of vision.'' John Hawkes plays a recently separated shoe salesman who becomes the unlikely love object of a flaky performance artist ( Ms. July).
 RIZE
 The fashion and celebrity photographer David LaChapelle directed this documentary about street dancing in South-Central Los Angeles.
 YES
 He is a Lebanese chef (Simon Abkarian); She is an American scientist (Joan Allen). This nameless pair carry on a passionate, cross-cultural extramarital affair in this new film by Britain's Sally Potter (''Orlando'' ). With Shirley Henderson and Sam Neill. A related article is on Page 15.
 WASABI TUNA
 Zany goings-on involving a gang of Anna Nicole Smith imitators, led by Alexis Arquette, during the West Hollywood Halloween celebration. Lee Friedlander directs.
 June 29
 A DECENT FACTORY
 This Finnish documentary looks into conditions at the Chinese factory where Nokia manufactures the components of its cellphones. They aren't good. Thomas Balmes directed.
 WAR OF THE WORLDS
 E.T., one hopes, is not playing for the opposing team in Steven Spielberg's return to H.G. Wells's often-dramatized, pioneering science-fiction story of 1898. Tom Cruise is the dockworker who has to get his wife (Miranda Otto) and his daughter (Dakota Fanning) out of the line of fire. David Koepp (''Spider-Man'' and other blockbusters) gets screenplay credit.
 July
 July 1
 THE BEAT THAT MY HEART SKIPPED
 One of the best regarded of France's younger generation of filmmakers, Jacques Audiard of ''Read My Lips,'' returns with a loose remake of James Toback's 1978 film ''Fingers.'' Romain Duris plays a young man torn between his career as a concert pianist and a family obligation to join his father's corrupt real estate empire.
 LILA SAYS
 A French teenager resolves to explore her sexuality, a problem given her Muslim background. Ziad Doueiri directed; with Vahina Giocante.
 REBOUND
 A hot-tempered college basketball coach, played by Martin Lawrence, tries to repair his public image by leading a team of high school girls to victory. This startlingly original concept reaches the screen the same day as the remake of ''The Bad News Bears''. Directed by Steve Carr, whose last hit was the Eddie Murphy-plus-cute-kids comedy, ''Daddy Day Care.''
 TROPICAL MALADY
 The Thai director Apichatpong Weerasethakul became a critics' darling with his 2000 ''Mysterious Object at Noon.'' His new film blends a love affair between a solider (Banlop Lomnoi) and a country boy (Sakda Kaewbuadee) with a Thai legend about a shaman with the power to transform himself into an animal.
 UNDEAD
 Another zombie movie joins the fray, this one directed by the Spierig brothers and starring Felicity Mason as a small-town girl who takes refuge in a farmhouse as the living dead take over.
 THE WORLD
 Jia Zhangke, the greatly gifted young Chinese director of ''Platform'' and ''Unknown Pleasures,'' returns with a panoramic drama set in a Beijing theme park that features miniature versions of landmarks from around the globe.
 July 8
 THE BEAUTIFUL COUNTRY
 From Norway's Hans Petter Moland (''Aberdeen''), the tale of a Vietnamese teenager (Damien Nguyen) who goes in search of his biological father (Nick Nolte) in America. Terrence Malick, one of the film's producers, is credited with the story idea. With Bai Ling and Tim Roth.
 CRoNICAS
 A Miami television reporter (John Leguizamo) of flexible morals searches for a serial killer in Ecuador. Sebastian Cordero directed this Spanish-language feature, which counts Guillermo del Toro and Alfonso Cuaron among its producers. With Alfred Molina and Leonor Watling.
 FANTASTIC FOUR
 Four superheroes for the price of one summer blockbuster ticket: Mr. Fantastic (Ioan Gruffudd), the Thing (Michael Chiklis), the Invisible Woman (Jessica Alba) and the Human Torch (Chris Evans) join forces to defeat the evil Doctor Doom (Julian McMahon). Fox went through a number of directors before handing the project to Tim Story ( ''Barbershop'' and ''Taxi''). And yes, Stan Lee does have a bit part.
 MURDERBALL
 A documentary, directed by Henry Alex Rubin and Dana Adam Shapiro, that takes us inside the fiercely competitive world of ''quad rugby,'' a contact sport played by quadriplegics in customized wheelchairs.
 SARABAND
 Made for Swedish television in 2003, Ingmar Bergman's film reunites Liv Ullmann and Erland Josephson for a continuation of Mr. Bergman's 1973 ''Scenes From a Marriage.'' The story picks up 30 years later as the battling spouses, long since divorced, try reconciliation.
 July 13
 HUSTLE AND FLOW
 Can a Memphis pimp (Terrence Howard) reinvent himself as a rap singer? Craig Brewer's film scored a $9 million sale to Paramount at Sundance this year. With Anthony Anderson, Isaac Hayes, Paula Jai Parker and Ludacris.
 ON THE OUTS
 The harsh lives of three Jersey City teenagers are revealed in a feature film by Lori Silverbush and Michael Skolnik. With Judy Marte, Paola Mendoza and Anny Mariano.
 July 15
 CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY
 The director Tim Burton brings his snarky Goth sensibility to a new version of Roald Dahl's children's book, about a candy mogul (Johnny Depp, looking disturbingly like Michael Jackson in the trailer) who takes a group of children on a tour of his operations. With Helena Bonham Carter, James Fox, Christopher Lee and Noah Taylor.
 HAPPY ENDINGS
 The writer-director Don Roos (''The Opposite of Sex'') juggles 10 main characters in this wide-ranging comedy. They include Lisa Kudrow as a woman faced with the prospect of meeting the child she gave up 19 years ago, and Maggie Gyllenhaal as a woman courting both a wealthy widower (Tom Arnold) and his gay son. A related article is on Page 3.
 SEARCHING FOR THE WRONG-EYED JESUS
 The hip country singer Jim White conducts a tour through the American South, featuring banjo players and evangelical churches. Andrew Douglas directed.
 WEDDING CRASHERS
 Two womanizing best friends, played by Owen Wilson and Vince Vaughn, discover that crashing weddings is a good way to meet women but run into trouble when one falls for the daughter (Rachel McAdams) of a powerful politician (Christopher Walken). Directed by David Dobkin (''Shanghai Knights'').
 July 22
 THE BAD NEWS BEARS
 With this new version of the 1978 hit, Richard Linklater earns himself the slack to make another ''Before Sunset'' by making another ''School of Rock'' -- a commercial project with an indie flavor. Billy Bob Thornton replaces Walter Matthau as the grumpy coach of a Little League team. With Greg Kinnear and Marcia Gay Harden.
 THE DEVIL'S REJECTS
 The musician and filmmaker Rob Zombie confects a sequel to his 2003 ''House of 1000 Corpses,'' a campy redo of ''Texas Chainsaw Massacre'' in which most of the characters lifted their names from Groucho Marx's repertory. Sid Haig returns as Captain J.T. Spaulding, Bill Moseley is Otis B. Driftwood and Tyler Maine is Rufus Firefly Jr.,all crazed psychos on the loose.
 THE EDUKATORS
 Three anarchists, among them Daniel Bruhl of ''Goodbye Lenin!,'' enjoy trashing the homes of rich people. But the fun fades when they're forced to kidnap a businessman who has caught them in the act. Hans Weingartner directed.
 THE ISLAND
 Michael Bay's first feature since ''Bad Boys II'' has a plot line similar to Robert S. Fiveson's 1979 ''Clonus Horror'': two lovers (Ewan McGregor and Scarlett Johansson) go on the run when they discover that they're human clones being raised for spare parts. With Djimon Hounsou, Steve Buscemi and Michael Clarke Duncan.
 LAST DAYS
 Michael Pitt of ''The Dreamers'' plays a lonely rocker in the final hours of his life, a figure loosely based on Kurt Cobain. Gus Van Sant directed this HBO Films production, said to be in the minimalist mode of his recent ''Elephant.'' With Lukas Haas, Asia Argento and Ricky Jay.
 9 SONGS
 ''The most sexually explicit film in the history of British cinema,'' The Guardian panted. Michael Winterbottom documents the love life of a pair of young rock fans over the course of a year; the nine songs include work from Primal Scream, Black Rebel Motorcycle Club and Franz Ferdinand. Kieran O'Brien and Margot Stilley star.
 NOVEMBER
 Greg Harrison's psychological puzzle casts Courteney Cox as a Los Angeles photographer whose boyfriend (James LeGros) has been killed in a convenience store robbery. As she tries to put her life back together, she finds her memories of the event falling apart.
 THE OVERTURE
 A Thai musician struggles to preserve his country's musical heritage during World War II. Based on the true story of Luang Pradit Phairao; directed by Itthi-sunthorn Wichailak.
 SHOUJYO: AN ADOLESCENT
 A 17-year-old woman begins an ill-advised affair with a middle-aged policeman in Eiji Okuda's Japanese feature.
 SUMMER STORM
 Marco Kreuzpaintner's German film chronicles the increasingly complex feelings that young Tobi (Robert Stadlober) has for his best friend Achim (Kostja Ullmann).
 THREE DANCING SLAVES
 Three brothers struggle to escape their domineering father and find themselves in a French film by the actor-turned-director Gael Morel (the star of Andre Techine's ''Wild Reeds'').
 July 27
 THE 3 ROOMS OF MELANCHOLIA
 Pirjo Honkasalo's Finnish documentary compares and contrasts the lives of orphaned children in a Russian military school and the parentless children of the Chechen conflict.
 July 29
 THE ARISTOCRATS
 George Carlin, Whoopi Goldberg, Drew Carey, Gilbert Gottfried, Bob Saget and Sarah Silverman are among the dozens of comedians who recite, with their own variations, what the filmmakers claim to be the world's dirtiest joke. Penn Jillette and Paul Provenza directed.
 THE BROTHERS GRIMM
 The mad visionary Terry Gilliam (''Brazil'') directs a screenplay by Ehren Kruger (the American adapter of the Japanese ''Ring'' films) that imagines the famous fairy tale collectors as a pair of traveling con men, played by Heath Ledger and Matt Damon. They tour the provinces of 19th-century Europe, casting out imaginary demons for modest fees, but are then called upon to face a genuine supernatural threat: an ageless sorceress (Monica Bellucci) who stays young by bathing in the blood of virgins. With Jonathan Pryce, Peter Stormare and Mackenzie Crook.
 NIGHTWATCH
 The young Russian filmmaker Timur Bekmambetov, called ''our Tarantino'' by the Russian director Nikita Mikhalkov, presents the first installment of a science-fiction trilogy based on the novels of Sergei Lukyanenko.
 SKY HIGH
 Mike Mitchell's teenage comedy takes as its premise a private high school for the privileged offspring of superheroes. An entering freshman, Will Stronghold (Michael Angarano), is the son of the legendary heroes the Commander (Kurt Russell) and Jetstream (Kelly Preston), But he has no superpowers of his own and finds himself humiliatingly assigned to ''sidekick'' classes. With Bruce Campbell and Dave Foley.
 STEALTH
 A fighter jet piloted by a computer develops a will of its own, posing a problem for Navy pilots (Josh Lucas, Jessica Biel and Jamie Foxx) who are assigned to bring it down before it strikes an urban center. The hardware specialist Rob Cohen (''The Fast and the Furious'' ) directs.
 TONY TAKITANI
 Based on a story by Haruki Murakami, this new film from Japan's Jun Ichikawa (''Osaka Story'') describes the tortured romance between a mild-mannered illustrator and a young woman addicted to high-priced designer clothing. With music by the celebrated Ryuichi Sakamoto.
 August
 Aug. 5
 BALZAC AND THE LITTLE CHINESE SEAMSTRESS
 This Chinese feature by Dai Sijie has been gathering a reputation at film festivals since it first surfaced in 2002; it's the story of a young intellectual banished to the countryside during the Cultural Revolution, where he falls in love with a tailor's daughter.
 BROKEN FLOWERS
 The writer-director Jim Jarmsuch goes on the road with Bill Murray, who plays a despondent single man making the rounds of his former lovers (Frances Conroy, Jessica Lange, Sharon Stone and Tilda Swinton) in search of the answer to a burning question: does he or does he not have a 19-year-old-son? With Julie Delpy and Jeffrey Wright.
 CRY WOLF
 When the body of a woman is discovered near their high school, a group of students decide to spread a false rumor that an imaginary serial killer, whom they call ''the Wolf,'' is on the prowl. But then more bodies turn up, each executed in a manner invented by ''the Wolf.'' Who's responsible? Jeff Wadlow directed; Julian Morris, Lindy Booth and Jared Padalecki star.
 GRIZZLY MAN
 Said to be a comeback for the 70's wunderkind Werner Herzog (''Aguirre, the Wrath of God''), this new documentary tells the story of Timothy Treadwell and Amie Huguenard, grizzly bear advocates killed in Alaska in 2003 while they were living among the beasts they loved. A related article is on Page 13.
 JUNEBUG
 Embeth Davidtz as a British art dealer whose trip to North Carolina has a double purpose: to meet the family of her new husband (Alessandro Nivola) and clinch a deal with a local artist. She draws support from her pregnant sister-in-law (Amy Adams). Phil Morrison directed.
 MUST LOVE DOGS
 The sitcom creator Gary David Goldberg (''Spin City,'' ''Family Ties'') directs for the big screen for the first time since ''Dad'' in 1989. Diane Lane stars, continuing her streak of romantic survivors (''Unfaithful,'' ''Under the Tuscan Sun'') as a recently divorced woman gingerly returning to the dating scene. With John Cusack, Dermot Mulroney, Christopher Plummer and Elizabeth Perkins.
 THE PINK PANTHER
 Steve Martin steps into the large shoes of Peter Sellers as the bumbling Inspector Clouseau, called on the job when a soccer coach's diamond ring -- the Pink Panther -- is stolen in front of a stadium crowd of 30,000. Kevin Kline is the long-suffering Chief Inspector Dreyfus; Jean Reno (an actual Frenchman) is Clouseau's loyal assistant. With Beyonce Knowles, Emily Mortimer and Henry Czerny; Shawn Levy, who directed Mr. Martin in ''Cheaper by the Dozen,'' is at the helm.
 2046
 More lush longing from the Hong Kong stylist Wong Kar-wai (''In the Mood for Love,'' 2000). Tony Leung Chiu-wai plays a character that may or may not be an extension of his role in ''Mood'' (he has the same name, if not quite the same characteristics). He's a writer of pulp fiction whose new science fiction novel is titled ''2046'' -- which just happens to be the number of the apartment down the hall from him, which is occupied by a vivacious Zhang Ziyi. Gong Li, Faye Wang and (fleetingly) Maggie Cheung appear as other women in his life. A related article is on Page 15.
 Aug. 10
 A STATE OF MIND
 The British documentarian Daniel Gordon follows two teenage girls as they undergo the grueling training program for one of North Korea's mass athletic exhibitions, staged for the pleasure of Kim Jong Il.
 Aug. 12
 THE BAXTER
 Michael Showalter directed and stars in a screwball comedy about a young man who warily prepares for his wedding to a domineering blonde (Elizabeth Banks). With Michelle Williams, Justin Theroux, Peter Dinklage and Paul Rudd. A related article is on Page 15.
 DARK WATER
 The Brazilian filmmaker Walter Salles (''The Motorcycle Diaries'') seems like an odd choice to direct the English-language remake of the Japanese horror film ''Dark Water,'' but ours is not to reason why. Jennifer Connelly stars as a recently divorced woman who moves into a creepy apartment building with her young daughter; the supernatural manifestations begin with a strange, spreading water stain on Ms. Connelly's ceiling. With John C. Reilly, Tim Roth and Dougray Scott.
 DEUCE BIGALOW: EUROPEAN GIGOLO
 Rob Schneider returns in a sequel to his eloquently titled ''Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo'' of 1999. Though it's six years later, Deuce apparently still hasn't learned all the tricks of his trade, so he attends a gigolo-training school in England (England?). Mike Bigelow (no relation) directed.
 EVERYTHING IS ILLUMINATED
 The actor Liev Schreiber wrote and directed this adaptation of Jonthan Safran Foer's novel about an American Jew (Elijah Wood) who travels to Ukraine in search of the woman who saved his grandfather from the Nazis.
 FOUR BROTHERS
 The director John Singleton, whose career has run from ''Boyz N the Hood'' in 1991 to ''2 Fast 2 Furious'' in 2003, returns with a remake of Henry Hathaway's 1965 John Wayne vehicle ''The Sons of Katie Elder.'' And why not? Mark Wahlberg, Andre 3000, Ice Cube and Tyrese play four (adopted) brothers who avenge their mother's death.
 GUYS AND BALLS
 From Germany, an instructive comedy about a gay baker from Dortmund who, after he's thrown off the local soccer team because of his sexual preferences, forms an all-gay team to take on his old mates. Sherry Horman directed.
 MOONLIGHT
 Love blossoms between an Afghan boy, who has been used and cast aside by drug smugglers, and the teenage girl who finds him, badly wounded, in her family's woodshed. From the Netherlands; directed by Paula van der Oest, whose ''Zus and Zo'' was a 2003 foreign-language Oscar nominee.
 PRETTY PERSUASION
 A Beverly Hills high school girl (Evan Rachel Wood) accuses her English teacher (Ron Livingston) of sexual harassment in a social satire directed by Marcos Siega. With James Woods, Jane Krakowski and Selma Blair.
 THE SKELETON KEY
 Kate Hudson as a private nurse assigned to a haunted mansion in Louisiana. Iain Softley, who made a lovely ''Wings of the Dove'' in 1997, directed this thriller, which may or may not be in the Jamesian tradition. With Peter Sarsgaard, John Hurt and Gena Rowlands. The prolific Ehren Kruger (''The Brothers Grimm'') wrote the script.
 Aug. 17
 THE UNTOLD STORY OF EMMETT LOUIS TILL
 Keith A. Beauchamp's documentary re-examines the case of Emmett Till, a black Mississippi teenager who was beaten and killed for the alleged crime of whistling at a white woman.
 Aug. 19
 ASYLUM
 While living with her husband, a psychiatrist (Ian McKellen), in a high-security mental hospital, Natasha Richardson finds herself strangely drawn to a patient (Marton Csokas) who brutally murdered his wife. David Mackenzie, of the accomplished Scottish film ''Young Adam,'' directs from a screenplay by Patrick Marber (''Closer'').
 THE 40 YEAR OLD VIRGIN
 Steve Carell as a sheltered electronics store employee whose life seems to be taking a turn for the better when he starts going out with a mother of three (Catherine Keener). But his dream girl insists on one thing: there will be no sex between them. Judd Apatow directed and wrote the script with Mr. Carell.
 RED-EYE
 On a night flight to Miami, Rachel McAdams is startled to learn that her seatmate (Cillian Murphy) is a professional assassin who has kidnapped her father to force her into helping him with his new assignment. What's a plucky young woman to do? The horror veteran Wes Craven directs from a script by Carl Ellsworth.
 ROMANCE AND CIGARETTES
 The actor-director John Turturro presents a naturalistic musical in the vein of ''Pennies From Heaven,'' set in a Brooklyn neighborhood where a blue collar worker (James Gandolfini) is forced to choose between his wife and his mistress. A big cast includes Susan Sarandon, Kate Winslet, Steve Buscemi, Christopher Walken, Mandy Moore, Mary-Louise Parker, Eddie Izzard and Elaine Stritch.
 SYMPATHY FOR MR. VENGEANCE
 A 2002 feature by the prodigiously talented Korean director Park Chanwook, whose ''OldBoy'' continues its march toward worldwide notoriety. Shin Ha-kyun stars as Ryu, a put-upon young man who allows himself to be persuaded by his blowsy girlfriend that the best way to raise money for his sister's kidney transplant is to kidnap his boss's daughter.
 VALIANT
 German falcons versus English carrier pigeons in World War II, as rendered in computer animation by a new company, Vanguard Animation, that's positioning itself as a rival to Pixar. The voice cast includes Ewan McGregor, Ricky Gervais, Tim Curry, John Cleese and Jim Broadbent; Gary Chapman directed.
 Aug. 26
 BACKWATER
 Agnes Bruckner and Bijou Phillips are among a group of young people battling the forces of voodoo in a Louisiana swamp. Jim Gillespie, of the venerable ''I Know What You Did Last Summer,'' is the director.
 THE CAVE
 A team of explorers (Cole Hauser, Morris Chestnut, Piper Perabo) goes in search of seven men swallowed up by the world's largest system of caves. But there's something else down there, too. Directed by Bruce Hunt.
 CHUMSCRUBBER
 Arie Posin's panoramic comedy-drama about suburban life is centered on Dean Stiffle (Jamie Bell), a high school student whose best friend (and his school's leading drug dealer) has just committed suicide. As the local teenagers struggle to get their hands on the dead boy's drug supply, the adults are all atwitter about the upcoming marriage of their town's popular mayor (Ralph Fiennes) to an interior decorator (Rita Wilson).
 THE CONSTANT GARDENER
 Adapted from John Le Carre's novel, this film is about a British diplomat (Ralph Fiennes) posted to a remote corner of Kenya whose unfaithful wife (Rachel Weisz) is found murdered. Stirred from his bureaucratic anomie, the diplomat mounts a worldwide effort to find her killer. The director, oddly, is Fernando Meirelles, whose stylish exercise in Brazilian miserablism, ''City of God,'' attracted critical attention in 2002.
 L'ESQUIVE
 Abdellatif Kechiche's modest French film caused a surprise by dominating the French Cesar Awards this year. Set in one of the grim housing projects of the Parisian suburbs, it observes an ethnically diverse group of teenagers as they attempt to mount a classical comedy by Marivaux.
 UNDISCOVERED
 An overlooked singer-songwriter (Steven Strait) becomes a star with the help of a model (Pell James) and an aspiring actress (Ashlee Simpson). Meiert Avis directed this ensemble comedy, which also features Kip Pardue, Carrie Fisher, Fisher Stevens and Peter Weller.
 Aug. 31
 WILLIAM EGGLESTON IN THE REAL WORLD
 The indie stalwart Michael Almereyda (''Nadia,'' ''Hamlet'') profiles the Memphis-based photographer William Eggleston as he goes about his work, observing the colorful oddities of American life.
 Late August
 SOMERSAULT
 Cast out after she's discovered in bed with her mother's boyfriend, 16-year-old Heidi (Abbie Cornish) heads off to discover her place in the world. First stop: a rundown ski resort where she searches for employment and affection. Cate Shortland's feature dominated the 2004 Australian Film Institute Awards. A related article is on Page 15.
 Sept. 2
 THE WOODS
 Something's lurking in the forest that surrounds the remote girls' boarding school that young Agnes Bruckner is attending, but the evil headmistress, Patricia Clarkson, won't say what. The director, Lucky McKee, made a solid debut with the 2002 direct-to-video thriller ''May.'' Compiled with the assistance of Suzanne O'Connor.

HEADLINE: Golf Homes Attract Even Those Who Don't Play

BYLINE: By ROBERT JOHNSON

 BODY:
IN the game of golf, a triple bogey -- three strokes over par on one hole -- is bad news. 
 The market for homes in communities located on golf courses would seem imperiled by an economic triple bogey of sorts right now: golf equipment sales are dwindling, the number of new golfers is flatter than a Texas fairway and golf courses are going out of business in the United States at about double the rate of a decade ago, 63 last year.
 None of that matters to Dr. Paul Capito, a radiologist who recently bought a 4,500-square-foot home on the golf course at Uwharrie Point in rural North Carolina about 50 miles west of Pinehurst. Dr. Capito doesn't even play golf. ''Never in my life,'' he said. 
 ''I have five children, ages 3 to 10, and I was drawn to the Uwharrie Point development because of the many amenities there besides golf: a beautiful lake, nature trails and excellent security,'' he said. ''It's gated and you have to talk to a real person to get in.'' There are also classes in art and gardening, and a guided trip to an area museum that he hopes will interest his children. ''The fact that it's a golf community is just part of the overall ambience; it's a lovely, quiet and safe place.'' He said houses there range from $650,000 to $1.8 million.
 Nongolfers like Dr. Capito are perhaps the major reason that the waning popularity of the links doesn't daunt the developers of golf-oriented subdivisions. In fact, the strategy of building golf courses as part of housing developments is a more popular play than ever. 
 Of the expected 150 new golf courses being built around the country this year, about 60 percent will be part of residential developments, according to the National Golf Foundation, a research group in Jupiter, Fla. In the 1990's, only about 30 percent of new courses were surrounded by homes. Only about one-fifth of the nation's 15,000 total golf facilities are in communities. Most of the rest are at individual country clubs or part of public park systems.
 So what's behind the optimism of golf community builders? They're discovering increasingly strong demand for housing in such subdivisions from nongolfers.
 ''Even though the popularity of golf isn't rising the way it once was, the premiums on golf development homes over comparable housing nearby that isn't on a course is now 30 percent to 40 percent in some areas,'' two or three times the typical markup in the 90's, said Jeff Woolson, managing director of CB Richard Ellis Golf Operations, a consulting firm in Carlsbad, Calif.
 One strategy of the developers who are building more golf community homes is that many are quietly cutting construction costs. The typical course and clubhouse in a community in the mid-90's cost $5 million to $10 million, said Tom Clark, a course designer in Kensington, Md. But lately the typical amount invested by developers is $2.5 million to $4 million, he said.
 One caveat presented by a bargain-priced golf course is that the surrounding community won't have the marketing power that comes from having a facility branded with the name of a famous professional player like Jack Nicklaus or Arnold Palmer. 
 Will cheaper golf courses affect the appreciation of home values in the community? Mr. Clark says no, because it won't matter to the nongolfers who have become the main buyers in these developments. Still, real estate agents say that all golf community shoppers should check into the quality of the course's construction and the developer's plans for maintaining it.
 Nongolfers are attracted to golf communities for reasons having to do with lifestyle, said Lewis Goodkin, a real estate researcher and consultant in Miami. ''We know that many people who buy homes on the ocean rarely, if ever, go swimming in the surf or own boats,'' he said. ''That isn't the point, and golf often isn't what lures them to golf communities.'' 
 Instead, the big draws include green space and peace and quiet. ''The golf course out back of your house can seem like an extension of your lot. It's a gardenlike atmosphere,'' Mr. Goodkin said. 
 The golf courses themselves are usually owned by the developer, with memberships available to people who live there but not required. Memberships are also sold to outsiders. 
 So attractive are the nongolf attributes of some of these developments that they thrive through the worst imaginable calamity: the golf course closes for lack of business. That happened in 2002 in the Bink's Forest community of West Palm Beach, Fla., where Larry Olevitch is among the 550 homeowners. ''The golf course folded, but our houses kept selling as fast as people would put them on the market,'' said Mr. Olevitch, a television marketing manager who paid $365,000 for his 3,500-square-foot house near the 17th tee in 1999. Similar houses in the Bink's Forest area are now selling for more than $600,000.
 There are various selling points of Mr. Olevitch's erstwhile golf course home, he said: one is that it is gated, and another is that it's ''a neighborhood of upscale homes and the golf course, while abandoned, has continued to be an amenity -- it's still quiet, green space.'' It is also, he said, in a desirable public school district. 
 The fact that the golf course was recently bought by a new owner with plans to refurbish it doesn't seem essential to Mr. Olevitch. ''I think that will be a good thing, but it hasn't been a disaster that the golf course closed,'' he said. 
 Some home buyers, in fact, find that life at the edge of a thriving golf course has drawbacks. ''You get the balls bouncing into your yard and banging into the house,'' said Mr. Goodkin, the consultant. ''Gardeners are always mowing and blowing to keep the course immaculate. And you keep hearing the players' expletives.'' 
 He lived on a golf course in Palm Springs, Calif., for several years but sold that house in the mid-90's. ''I just got tired of living with golf,'' said Mr. Goodkin, who still describes himself as ''a golf devotee.'' 
 But many home buyers in golf developments are willing to tolerate the golf course in order to be part of such a community's overall lifestyle. ''Golf is part of a package of amenities they're seeking; the main thing about the golf for some buyers is the prestige factor,'' Mr. Clark said. ''People don't go around saying, 'I live in a place that has a great bingo night.' Even if they don't play golf, they like to say, 'I live in a golf course home.'''

Mike Norton, below, a marketing director at Uwharrie Point in rural North Carolina. Dr. Paul Capito, below right, bought a home in the development even though he doesn't play golf.
