HEADLINE: McMansions, Bash-and-Builds, Bigfoots

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
AFTER her husband died, Barbara Wirkus decided it was time to sell the house in Union where they had lived for 38 years and raised four sons. She moved into bungalow, ''a lovely little home'' on a cul-de-sac in Kenilworth, a town the 72-year-old widow describes six years later as ''a town that time forgot.'' She planted a garden and made friends with her neighbors. 
 But soon her next-door neighbor added a porch and a family room to his house -- which sits on a 50-by-100-foot lot -- bringing the house eight feet closer and looming a story and a half above hers. Today, the neighbor's house is so close that the light from the motion detector shines into her house, Ms. Wirkus said, and ''cats or rabbits set it off 20 times a night.''
 Her experience is not unusual. You see them -- oversize houses -- in the more-established and densely populated communities like Cresskill, Short Hills and Westfield, where older, smaller houses once stood, and they now dwarf the Cape Cods, low ranches and even the elegant, turn-of-the-century homes. 
 Indeed, the number of oversize houses from 3,000 to 10,000 square feet with entrances like Tara, windows like European cathedrals and garages like small municipal lots has increased so drastically in the last decade that many local governments from Bergen County to Cape May County -- where the character of neighborhoods is threatened -- find themselves struggling to establish new zoning ordinances or rewriting existing ones in an effort to restrict the size of the new structures. 
 These sprawling new homes have as many names as there are styles, from ''trophy homes'' to ''monster homes'' and ''McMansions,'' ''starter castles'' to ''plywood palaces.'' In North Jersey, detractors call them ''bash and builds'' and ''bigfoots.'' But whatever the name, they present neighbors with a sudden expanse of towering wall to look at, blocking sunlight, altering the streetscape and even changing the character of the neighborhood.
 ''What people may be objecting to is the fact these homes are so out of sync with the traditional style and character of their towns,'' said Tim Dillingham, executive director of the American Littoral Society, an environmental group. ''I think people recognize that a sense of place is very important and that at some level the negative reaction to these teardowns and out-of-scale houses is a reaction to that sense of place being destroyed.'' 
 In 2002, a report sponsored by the National Trust for Historic Preservation, ''Taming the Teardown Trend,'' said that demolitions were approaching ''epidemic proportions'' in historic neighborhoods, and that 100 communities in 20 states had experienced significant numbers of teardowns.
 Adrian Scott Fine, director of the northeast office of the National Trust in Philadelphia and an author of the report, said there had been no statistical follow-up, but that through discussions with communities, he thought teardowns had gone beyond the 100 communities.
 ''If anything, it's gotten much more exacerbated,'' Mr. Fine said. ''The demand for the big house seems to be alive and well. The real estate market seems to be able to move these houses fairly well.''
 In New Jersey alone, between 1998 and 2003 the number of demolition permits issued by municipalities rose to 5,006 from 2,967, according to the state Department of Community Affairs. And while many of these involved replacing older housing in cities like Camden, Newark, and Paterson, planners said a sizable number could be linked to the construction of larger homes.
 Under current land-use law, municipalities cannot stop a homeowner or builder from tearing down a house. Nor, from an aesthetic point of view, can they dictate what a house can look like. But they do have the right to regulate size. 
 In a major victory for municipalities over builders, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled in 2003 that the town of Fair Haven, in Monmouth County, had the right to put a cap on the floor area of a single-family house regardless of lot size. 
 ''What Fair Haven did was it upheld an ordinance which limited in absolute terms the size of a house in terms of square feet,'' said a Jeffrey Zenn, the lawyer for the Tenafly Planning Board.
 Tenafly, which had 115 teardowns over five years, is reworking its zoning ordinance, but it is having a problem defining exactly what a McMansion is. 
 ''A McMansion means different things to different people,'' Mr. Zenn said. "My definition of a McMansion is not your definition. You may say the ugly house with all kinds of turrets is a McMansion. I can say it's just in bad taste."

McGreevey Took Aim
 Former Gov. James E. McGreevey came up with a plan to inhibit the growth of oversize houses when he reached for the word McMansions in his 2003 State of the State address and attacked them as contributing to ''mindless sprawl.'' 
 But Mr. McGreevey's proposal for a 1 percent tax on new houses selling for more than $1 million died with his political career last year, and acting Gov. Richard J. Codey -- a sponsor of fast-track legislation in the Senate aimed at speeding the approval process for developers -- has shown no inclination to tilt at McMansions.
 To be sure, opinions vary wildly on the appropriateness of larger and larger houses -- the most obvious statement homeowners can make about their station in life and their bank balance.
 John Barba, president of Barba Builders, a third-generation homebuilder based in Chatham and former president of the New Jersey Builders Associaton, said he was not against regulations limiting the size of new houses as long as they were fair. ''The town should not be in the business of preventing improvements to residential real estate,'' Mr. Barba said. 
 The growth of oversize houses -- very often teardowns -- is a relatively recent phenomenon, a little more than 10 years old, said Thomas Wright, executive vice president of the Regional Plan Association, with many of them having attached three- and four- car garages facing the street.
 One such garage in Princeton, Mr. Wright commented, was so large it came to be known as ''the Taj Garage.''
 ''Communities have always been renewing themselves since Colonial times,'' he said, ''but this new wave of massive residential structures represents a real shift.''
 Robert E. Lang, an urban affairs specialist who is director of the Metropolitan Institute at Virginia Tech, said that although some people are critical of newer, oversize houses because of the amount of energy they require, they are part of a trend in American construction.
 ''This is an extension of a constant redefinition of the good life,'' Dr. Lang said. ''In the 1950's it was a station wagon and meatloaf. The good life today might mean you have a master bedroom the size your parents' ranch house.''
 Livio Mancino, a former mayor of Kenilworth, is upset with the proliferation of oversize houses -- particularly since two of them are rising behind his house on a 100-by-100-foot lot where a ranch house stood.
 Unlike other houses in the area that have 30-foot setbacks, the subdivided property behind Mr. Mancino will have a 15-foot setback that he says will obscure the sight lines of a busy intersection that children use on the way to St. Theresa's, a nearby elementary school.
 ''The houses make it a hazard for the children,'' he said. ''And aesthetically, they're an eyesore.
 The 70-year old Mr. Mancino -- who as mayor once put up signs urging the placement of traffic lights and even laid down in the street to make his point -- said he was about to dig in his heels once again. ''I'm erecting a sign on my property telling people what's going up,'' he said.

Will Values Rise or Fall?
 Conventional wisdom usually dictates that most houses appreciate in value after nearby homes are renovated. But in these cases, James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers, is not so sure.
 ''It may go down, because if you're living next to a McMansion and it's towering over you, your house becomes less valuable,'' Dr. Hughes said. ''But it may become more valuable if the house you have becomes a target for McMansion. It's a potential site for rebuilding.''
 On the other hand, rising home prices are no friend of first-time buyers. Jeffrey Tittel, executive director of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club, contended that the boom in teardowns and oversize houses was keeping buyers out of the market and middle-class families out of some towns that were once within their financial reach.
 ''It squeezes the middle class and even the upper middle class,'' Mr. Tittel said. ''A family of four making $150,000 a year can't afford a million-and-a-half-dollar home.''
 Of course, not everyone is as critical of the larger homes as Mr. Tittel is.
 In Saddle River, a house going up with turrets, at least three large chimneys, cupolas, arched windows and a slate roof seems to fill most of the two-acre plot on which it sits. The back of the house is only a short distance from Hillsdale, which two years ago passed an ordinance curtailing the growth of such large houses. 
 ''We saw some homes we thought were a bit large for the size of the lot in Hillsdale but thankfully not as bad as in other towns,'' said Dennis S. Deutsch, Hillsdale's mayor. 
 The house does not bother Tom Beatini, its closest neighbor in Hillsdale, although he did have one reservation. ''We're on a well,'' Mr. Beatini said, ''and we're wondering if they're going to put an underground sprinkler system in for what little lawn they have and how the amount of water will affect the water in the neighborhood.''
 Another neighbor, John M. Kolvek, said, ''I haven't spoken to anyone, but it's fine with me.'' His son, Chris, called it a monstrosity but added: ''I don't know if anyone's upset here. We're more astounded.''
 Defenders say the larger houses are only symbols of the desire for bigger living spaces that took root in the boom years in the 1990's. A study issued in 2002 by the National Association of Home Builders found that the size of the American house had grown while the size of the plot on which it sat had shrunk.
 In 1987, the average house was 1,905 square feet; by 2002, the average size was 2,320 square feet. Yet the average lot size decreased from 17,600 square feet in 1987 to 16,400 in 2002 and, according to Michael Carliner, an economist with the association, it went down to 15,788 in 2003. 
 ''I think it's a change in culture and fashion,'' Mr. Carliner said. ''People are willing to accept a small lot for more house.''
 Joanne Harkins, director of land use planning for the New Jersey Builders Association, said: ''You have a lot of houses that were built sometimes 100 years ago and even 50 years ago, and these houses were for a different era and generations. People want different houses now. The look and the heating and plumbing are obsolete, windows not double-paned.'' 
 Today, Ms. Harkins said, developers build what the towns will allow. 
 In many towns -- particularly those close to New York, where developable land is scarce -- the property has become more valuable than the house itself, leading builders to tear them down and build larger ones.

Brisk Activity in Westfield
 During a recent drive through Westfield, a prosperous middle-class town in Union County, James Foerst, a councilman who is chairman of the Code Review and Town Property Committee, said he bought his house because he liked the fact that it was built in 1914 and had character. But many houses like his, he said, are being torn down by developers and replaced by larger ones.
 From 1998 through 2003, according to the state Department of Community Affairs, Westfield issued 77 demolition permits -- 38 in 2003 alone. Driving along Coolidge Street, Mr. Foerst noted that within the last two years, seven houses had been replaced by far larger ones. 
 ''It's very common for a builder to pay $500,000 to knock a house down and put up a $1.3 million house, which when you look at it doesn't look like what you thought anyone would spend a million dollars on,'' Mr. Foerst said. 
 To Susan Burrows Farber, deputy executive director of external affairs for New Jersey Future, the figures tell a different story.
 Ms. Farber said teardowns as a tool of development can help keep a community vital, especially when dilapidated buildings near transit lines in downtown areas are demolished and rebuilt.
 ''The issue becomes a concern when what was demolished is being replaced with a structure inconsistent with the character of the community,'' she said. ''We would argue that is not smart growth.''
 Jennifer Evans-Cowley, a planner and assistant professor at the Austin E. Knowlton School of Architecture at Ohio State University, said municipalities began regulating oversize houses about five years ago. 
 ''Some are putting limits on the floor-area ratio,'' Dr. Evans-Cowley said, ''some are putting limits on maximum lot coverage, and some are putting in height limitations.''. 
 As she put it: ''When you have one or two oversize houses, it's no big deal. But when you begin to have more, then people feel there is a need to find out what's going on and it's up to the community to investigate.'' 
 In Millburn, where there have been 84 teardowns in the last six years, mainly in the Short Hills area, the town introduced an ordinance in January limiting the size of teardowns, only to run into a hailstorm of criticism from builders, architects and others at several public hearings. Some homeowners expressed concern that their property would lose value if the expansion possibilities were limited. 
 A subcommittee of the planning board has reworked the ordinance, simplifying the language. (One criticism at public hearings was that it was too complicated, according to the subcommittee chairman, Michael Gorman.) After another public meeting this month, Mr. Gorman said he hoped the council would be able to act.
 ''What we're trying to do essentially is two things,'' Mr. Gorman said. ''We're trying to control the size of house being built and control the lot where they can be built.''
 He added: ''The balance we're trying to attain is to create changes to our ordinance that would still have people think about Millburn as a place to come where they can build the home of their dreams. And we want to balance that with a respect for the privacy of existing residents..''
 Planners in Princeton Borough have also been fine-tuning an ordinance introduced last spring after holding several neighborhood meetings, said Lee Solow, the region's planning director. 
 ''We're starting the process up again with different neighborhoods and we're going to go back to the planning board with a verbal report,'' Mr. Solow said.
 Upper Saddle River is reconsidering an ordinance after residents rejected an earlier one in a nonbinding referendum last November aimed at limiting new homes to less than 7,000 square feet. 
 Westfield has appropriated $50,000 to study the types of housing in town before drafting an ordinance aimed at setting standards, Mr. Foerst said.
 And Cresskill passed an ordinance several years ago limiting the footprint of a house to 20 percent of the lot, Mayor Ben Romeo said. 
 ''It took two years to hammer out the ordinance,'' Mayor Romeo said, ''and it is still a work in progress.
 ''We went to the building department and got all the builders' names and called them to a meeting to tell us what they need by way of size to make a profit,'' Mayor Romeo added. ''Told them, 'Tell us what you need, not what you want. You want 30-foot lot coverage but that's not going to happen.' Invariably, everyone worked with us.''
 In the face of more and more ordinances limiting the size of houses, Ms. Harkins of the New Jersey Builders Association said that such measures could drive away home buyers and builders wanting to do business in those towns.

Builders May 'Look Elsewhere'
 ''They would look elsewhere,'' she said. ''They probably would not invest significantly in those municipalities.'' 
 Dr. Lang of Virginia Tech carried that thought further. ''If you have houses built in the 1970's when 2,000 square feet was a lot of room and you set that against the modern standard which is 3,000 feet and larger, and then you frustrate the market's development, you may not be that upscale a town forever,'' Dr. Lang said. ''You're also pushing people into new construction somewhere else rather than infill housing.''
 For his part, Ron Emrich, executive director of Preservation New Jersey, dismissed such reasoning and said people needed a sense of place that oversize houses could not give.
 ''As big and ostentatious as these houses tend to be, they also tend to look the same,'' Mr. Emrich said. ''The McMansion in Closter is going to look much like the one in Colt's Neck. I think people are tired of that. People want a place that's different and unique where they can say they are from, someplace rather than just anyplace.''

HEADLINE: He's a Light To the World's Poor

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LASER

DATELINE: BLOOMFIELD 

 BODY:
ONE-THIRD of the world's population has no access to electricity but Phil LaRocco is working on that problem, one watt at a time. 
 From a small office here, Mr. LaRocco and the nonprofit company he directs, E+Co., put together money from foundations, governments and investors, and lend it to entrepreneurs in Africa, Asia and Latin America. These local businesses then deliver solar power and other forms of clean energy to the poorest of the poor. 
 ''Energy is the key to alleviating poverty,'' Mr. LaRocco said bluntly during a recent conversation. ''Without energy to improve your quality of life, to make an income -- and the fact that you spend your time going out to collect wood and water -- you're trapped in a vicious cycle. It's a no-brainer. With energy, many things are possible. Without energy, very little is possible.'' 
 Specifically: without energy, people in developing countries can't study at night or sew. And without clean energy, they can't cook indoors without polluting the air. ''You don't want to be burning sticks in the house while your 8-month-old infant is sucking in the fumes,'' Mr. LaRocco said.
 Since its creation in 1994, E+Co. has sponsored 120 businesses in 35 countries. These companies now deliver energy to nearly two million people. 
 Mr. LaRocco could supply the energy needs of a small nation all by himself. A compact man with short gray hair and a close-trimmed gray beard, he is (let's get this out of the way) a dynamo. He speaks knowledgeably and enthusiastically about subjects as diverse as carbon dioxide offsets, the Civil War and wood stoves, and admits that he enjoys teaching children to spray Reddi-wip into their mouths. A gap between his front teeth shows when he laughs, which he does often.
 And his work makes a difference to people in poverty. Dana Younger, a renewable-energy adviser at the World Bank, described an E+Co. business in Honduras that sells solar photovoltaic panels to the rural poor: ''The systems provide relatively small amounts of electricity, four to six hours a day, generally enough to power a radio or a black-and-white television or a fan. A tailor can run a small sewing machine, or have enough lighting to work at night, and to displace a kerosene lantern or candles. This product has had a very direct impact on the lives of a large number of people.''
 Those who have financed E+Co. include the MacArthur Foundation, Nike, the Body Shop, Ted Turner's United Nations Foundation and the United States Agency for International Development. In the future, Mr. LaRocco wants to shift from grant money toward loans from private investors. 
 How does he answer investors who ask why they should accept a lower rate of return than they could get elsewhere? ''If you have a choice between investing at 10 percent in a company that causes cancer and 9 percent in a company that cures cancer, which would you choose?''
 Colleagues say he always says exactly what he thinks. ''There were some meetings on clean energy in New York, following the Rio Earth Summit,'' said Mr. Younger, referring to the 1992 summit. ''These U.N. meetings are often couched in obscure, bureaucratic language, and Phil just punctured all that with some very telling examples. He made people sit up and notice that, if anything, these problems are getting bigger, not smaller, and the current approaches are not sufficient to solve the problem.''
 Mr. LaRocco explained why he is the way he is: ''I was a blue-collar kid in Brooklyn. My father was a U.P.S. driver. Part of that background is saying what you see.''
 Eric Usher, a clean-energy specialist with the United Nations Environmental Program, admires Mr. LaRocco's ability to bridge cultural gaps. ''He's very effective at connecting with people, from high officials at the World Bank to the Zambian Women's Union,'' Mr. Usher said. ''These are people who are very far from Brooklyn, but he's able to bring them around and motivate them. When he leaves the room, people say, 'O.K., this is on the edge of what we would normally consider, but let's give it a try.'''
 Christine Eibs Singer, who has worked closely with Mr. LaRocco for 20 years, says he has an insatiable appetite for information. ''The International Energy Association recently put out the World Energy Outlook, a 1,200-page book of statistics and forecasts,'' Ms. Singer said. ''Phil devoured it in a weekend.''
 Mr. LaRocco insists that the future of energy lies with the small entrepreneur. ''For close to 50 years, the whole development community has operated from the top down, with big organizations as the prime movers,'' he said. ''To be fair, an awful lot of homes, millions and millions of homes, have electricity from the centralized approach. But it's reached its limit. While it reaches a vast number of people, it has failed to reach an amazingly large number of people.'' 
 And large power projects -- oil or natural gas or large hydroelectric dams -- come with harsh consequences for the environment and for the people who live near them. ''Dams often require relocations,'' Mr. LaRocco said. ''And if you burn coal or wood indoors, the air becomes disgusting, causing respiratory illnesses.''
 According to Mr. Younger, traditional financiers would never lend to most of the businesses that E+Co. supports. ''Basically, the companies are viewed as very bad credit risks,'' he said. 
 Even so, with a self-described bean counter in charge, E+Co. has recouped the great majority of its loans. ''We've been very rigorous,'' Mr. LaRocco said. ''We're confident that we can offer investors returns of 3 to 5 percent. We in turn lend that to local entrepreneurs at 8 to 10 percent. The difference is so we can cover the roughly 11 percent that don't repay their loans.''
 A big question remains, though: Can E+Co.'s small-enterprise approach really supply energy to the two billion people who don't have it -- or even make a dent?
 Mr. LaRocco's short answer is that he doesn't expect E+Co. to create the necessary businesses directly. ''The hope is that governments will start doing this on their own. We're trying to create that point in the lever where suddenly everybody says, 'Yeah, this is the way to go.''' 
 Mr. LaRocco attended St. Francis College in Brooklyn at night while working as a bank teller. Before forming E+Co., he worked at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for 20 years, starting out as a parking lot auditor in Newark and ending up, 12 jobs later, as the director of world trade and economic development. When he left in 1990, lured away by ''an entrepreneurial itch,'' he had a staff of 550 and an annual budget of roughly $750 million, and was responsible for the World Trade Center. 
 ''The biggest change was going from a big office and a big staff to one, two, three people,'' he said. ''We started out with just a fax machine.''
 E+Co. has a staff of 22 worldwide: in Costa Rica, Bolivia, Brazil, South Africa, Thailand, the Netherlands -- and Bloomfield, N.J., which Mr. LaRocco calls ''the clean-energy capital of the developing world.''
 After having finished 10 marathons, he reported that his knees still work, but added, ''My hip we won't discuss.'' He lives in nearby Glen Ridge with his wife, Patricia, an accountant, and their teenage daughter. 
 The World Energy Outlook (that tome he polished off in a weekend) forecasts that $7 trillion will be spent supplying the growing energy needs of the developing world between now and 2030 -- and that 85 percent of that amount will be spent on fossil fuels. 
 ''The question isn't one of money,'' Mr. LaRocco said. ''We're going to spend it one way or another. I want to bend that $7 trillion so it's spent in a sustainable manner. If you want people to not invest in a coal plant, you have to give them a viable alternative.''

HEADLINE: Forrester's Bookkeeping Is Short on Spending Cuts

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson. 
Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

 BODY:
In 15th-century Italy, double-entry bookkeeping was invented, and that system of balancing income and expenses has provided the iron logic of money management for businesses and governments ever since. 
 Or almost ever since. 
 Lately, we have been encountering political leaders and aspirants to leadership who have found it expedient to practice a kind of single-entry political bookkeeping --where there is a lot of debate about the income side, paid for by, ugh, taxes, but an echoing silence about the expense side, which pays for many vital public services and public-payroll jobs, jobs, jobs.
 In the debate over taxes, the spending side of the ledger seems to have all but disappeared. And stranger still, the people who have made it disappear tend to be Republicans, the people who used to be known as the bookkeeping class in this country, but who have lately discovered that you can score points by cutting taxes without worrying very much about the other side of the ledger. 
 In 1993, a Republican unknown running as an underdog against an incumbent Democratic governor of New Jersey was getting little traction until, fairly late in the campaign, she made a breathtakingly simple promise: if elected, she would cut state income taxes by 10 percent for three consecutive years.
 The woman with the promise and a kiss, Christie Whitman -- helped by Jim Florio's unpopularity -- won on this pledge, and her simple promise to cut taxes now and figure out how to balance the books later became a kind of mantra for Republicans.
 John Rowland of Connecticut -- who these days is passing his time at a minimum-security facility in Pennsylvania -- actually called himself ''a Whitman Republican'' in his winning gubernatorial campaign.
 Now we have a Republican administration in Washington that has also focused on cutting the income side of the ledger without worrying too much about the expense side.
 And here at home, the front-runner for the Republican nomination for governor, Doug Forrester, has updated Mrs. Whitman career-making promise. Only he promises to cut property taxes with a state-paid offset on each municipal tax bill -- by 10 percent a year for three years.
 Mrs. Whitman was lucky and caught the dot-com wave of economic growth to pay for part of her budget cut, and the rest she borrowed. President Bush is still waiting for his wave, so he is borrowing heavily to cover his deficit. 
 The specifics in Mr. Forrester's proposed cuts become vague when it comes to achieving the offsetting savings. He will impose purchasing efficiencies, he said, and cut waste, corruption and patronage. 
 This is a shaky promise -- the state has presumably been cutting waste for decades now, and ridding it of corruption is a Sisyphean task of limited likelihood -- so Mr. Forrester would have to do some fancy bookkeeping to make the income and the outgo sides of the ledger balance, as the state Constitution requires, under his tax-cut promise.
 And as Joseph L. Seneca, a professor at the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers, said, ''At some point you've got to look at expenses.''
 Let's take a look at both sides of the ledger under the Forrester plan to cut taxes.
 New Jerseyans pay about $17 billion a year in local property taxes. Take $3.6 billion out for commercial and industrial property, which Mr. Forrester has not promised to cut, and, say, a hundred million in taxes on second homes that are also off the pledge, and we are left with $13.3 billion in residential property taxes.
 Even assuming that amount stays level -- and it will not -- Mr. Forrester promises to have the state pick up the tab for $1.33 billion the first years, $2.66 billion the second year, and $3.99 billion the third year and for every year thereafter for each homeowner's property tax bill. 
 And, he says, it will be done without touching the single greatest taxpayer expense, the public payroll.
 ''We are not laying off rank-and-file state workers -- absolutely not,'' said Heather Grizzle, Mr. Forrester's policy director. ''They are not the problem. We're talking about the political patronage employees that give the hard-working state employees a bad name.''
 Mr. Forrester got a terrific boost in this pledge from the Democrats last week when Devon Brown, acting Gov. Richard J. Codey's corrections commissioner, helpfully testified that he had been forced to hire 14 patronage appointees. But even if every political hack were somehow winkled out of the public payroll, Governor Forrester (let's just presume for a moment) would start each year with a huge built-in deficit, even assuming the recurring deficits that have so bedeviled the State House recently do not recur.
 Brigid Harrison, associate professor of political science at Montclair State University, says Mr. Forrester's promise is tailored to the primary, not to a general election.
 ''I think these are the promises of someone who is fighting in a Republican primary,'' Professor Harrison said. ''This appeals to conservatives within the Republican party that he needs to worry about right now.'' 
 The waste and fraud that Mr. Forrester says he will root out, and the efficiencies he, as a successful businessman, will impose, would already be there if it were that easy, Ms. Harrison said. 
 ''The reality is that you can't reduce someone's taxes 30 percent and not cut spending.''
 Not if you want to balance the books.

HEADLINE: My Fake Retirement

BYLINE: By WARREN ST. JOHN

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
AN implicit promise of American-style capitalism is that after years of toil and with a little luck, sometime in your late 60's or early 70's you will be able to put on a pair of jean shorts and some Velcro sneakers, buy a condo in a Florida retirement community and spend the rest of your natural life sitting by a pool, with ready access to golf and bingo.
 But for Rodney Rothman, a former head writer for ''Late Show With David Letterman,'' 40 years was too long to wait. Burned out after years of writing jokes (well, a few years anyway) and unemployed after the situation comedy he was working on was canceled, Mr. Rothman decided to hop off the workaday hamster wheel of life in Manhattan and Los Angeles and give retirement in Florida a try -- at the age of 28. 
 Through a roommate agency he found a room in the condominium of a widow with two cats and three birds at Century Village, an 8,500-resident retirement community in Boca Raton. ''I wanted to see if the hard work I was doing was going to lead to anyplace I wanted to be,'' said Mr. Rothman, who is now 31. ''And I figured: I'm Jewish. I'm going to end up there anyway.'' 
 Few people younger than 35 undertake any activity these days without first contemplating its potential value as intellectual property, and that is especially the case for a comedy writer with an agent, a manager and a host of contacts in the TV world. 
 From an intellectual property point of view, Mr. Rothman's six-month sojourn at Century Village may go down as one of the most productive retirements in history. He has turned his account of life there into a book called ''Early Bird'' (Simon & Schuster) and a television pilot under development with NBC Universal; the book was published this week, and Mr. Rothman will find out this month whether NBC is going to pick up the TV show. 
 He is quick to acknowledge the commercial value of what he calls his ''stupid little idea,'' but he said he hung around Century Village for so long simply because retired life, he learned, was pretty chill. ''It's not like I can lie and say I don't know what you can do with ideas,'' Mr. Rothman said on Tuesday as he poked at a Greek salad at an outdoor restaurant in the Silver Lake section of Los Angeles. ''But when you work in a business like mine, people are judging you all the time. There was something very attractive to me about going to a world full of grandmothers and grandfathers who weren't going to judge me.''
 Mr. Rothman described his writing motif as cowardly gonzo.
 ''I go gonzo to, like, the safest places on earth,'' he said.
 The last time Mr. Rothman attempted his cowardly gonzo shtick, things did not go so well. In 2000 he began showing up for work at a failing Internet company that did not employ him, and no one noticed. He wrote about this 17-day adventure as a phony employee in an article in The New Yorker titled ''My Fake Job,'' but ran into trouble when it was learned that he had not received a free massage at the office, as he claimed in the article, and that his mother had worked at the company before he decided to sneak in. 
 The magazine issued an apology, and Mr. Rothman's name began to show up on lists of disgraced journalists, never mind that with a career in joke writing he had never considered himself a journalist in the first place.
 Of the fabrication Mr. Rothman said, ''It was stupid, and I regret it.''
 That episode raises the question, How much of ''Early Bird'' is true? 
 Mr. Rothman insists it is all real, though he said that certain names had been changed, and that some characters had died since his reporting, making his accounts of his time with them essentially unverifiable. Mindful of the New Yorker controversy, Mr. Rothman said he had hired an independent fact checker for the book; GQ magazine checked an excerpt from it without incident.
 Toni Gleeson, an administrator at Century Village, confirmed that Mr. Rothman had spent months there with residents. Amy Ballinger, a 95-year-old foul-mouthed comedian Mr. Rothman writes about in the book, said his portrayal of their time together was accurate. Asked if she found Mr. Rothman's book funny, Ms. Ballinger said, ''It could have been funnier.''
 Mr. Rothman suggested his book was best appreciated not as straight nonfiction but as personal essays that employ comic hyperbole in the style of David Sedaris.
 ''I'm not a journalist,'' he said. ''I think my track record shows that.''
 AS whimsical, Plimptonesque participatory journalism gags go, Mr. Rothman's brief retirement is an effective one, providing plenty of punch line opportunities for a former late-night comedy writer. 
 But the real appeal of his book is the insight the relatively young author gains into the world of America's elderly, one he knows he will someday join in earnest -- if he is lucky. It's a place where dinner is eaten at 5 p.m. (when he would normally be having a late lunch, Mr. Rothman writes); where the softball teams play with two home plates, positioned side by side, to prevent collisions between catcher and runner; and where ambulances continually ghost by, reminding residents of their mortality.
 Retirement communities, Mr. Rothman is surprised to learn, are slow-motion versions of high school, where cliques dominate the social landscape, leaving many feeling excluded and lonely. Mr. Rothman's elderly roommate, for example, who is on antidepressants to combat the misery of losing her husband two years before, is spurned by women who hang out together at the pool because they find her ''weird.'' 
 Mr. Rothman described himself as a joker from an early age. Even his birth was a kind of punch line. He was the second born of twins, but until he appeared, feet first, his parents were expecting only one child. ''No one knew I was coming,'' he said. ''I was late and I came out the wrong way. That's followed me through life.'' 
 Mr. Rothman grew up in Queens, then Scarsdale, and began pursuing a career in comedy as a teenager. At 16, he said, inspired by an arrest of Todd Bridges, a star of ''Diff'rent Strokes,'' he came up with a joke he thought was so funny that it deserved a national audience. (''Todd Bridges was arrested today,'' the joke went. ''Gary Coleman's reaction to the news was, 'Whatchoo talkin' 'bout?''') 
 Such was his faith in the line that the young Mr. Rothman and his friends took a train to Manhattan and hung out in the lobby of Rockefeller Center, hoping to find someone who would put the joke on the Weekend Update segment of ''Saturday Night Live.'' Instead, he said, a security guard told them to get lost. 
 MR. ROTHMAN went to Middlebury College in Vermont, where, he said, a dearth of funny people ''helped me to develop a false sense of confidence that has carried me far.''
 In college Mr. Rothman got his chance to submit jokes to ''Saturday Night Live.'' Through a friend of a friend, he learned that Norm Macdonald, then the host of Weekend Update, would pay $50 for jokes faxed in by freelance writers if he used them on the air. After many failed attempts, Mr. Rothman was at a fraternity party when he watched Mr. Macdonald close his segment with a joke Mr. Rothman had written about Jodie Foster, then starring in ''Nell,'' and Tom Hanks, who that year (1994) starred in ''Forrest Gump.'' The actors, the joke went, had both received Oscar nominations in the category of Best Retard. 
 ''Everything went into slow motion,'' Mr. Rothman said, recalling the moment. ''I remember jumping in the air and making a noise I could never recreate.''
 Right after college he got a 13-week contract as a junior writer at ''Late Show With David Letterman.'' 
 ''It's awfully hard to be funny when you know that every bad joke you write can get you fired,'' he said.
 Nevertheless he managed to hang on to his job. He wrote jokes for Viewer Mail, and for a while he wrote remote segments, filmed bits in which Mr. Letterman knocks on doors in the suburbs or harasses customers at the drive-through of a Taco Bell. Improbably, at 24, he was promoted to head writer.
 That job lasted two stressful years, Mr. Rothman said. Then he struck out on his own. He wrote the ''My Fake Job'' article for The New Yorker, tried his hand at sitcom writing, working with the director Richard Linklater on a pilot and with Judd Apatow, an executive producer of ''Freaks and Geeks,'' on the Fox show ''Undeclared.'' When that show was canceled, he said, ''that was kind of like the end.'' 
 ''I was floundering,'' he said.
 For a book of essays he had sold to Simon & Schuster, Mr. Rothman decided to write about buying a retirement condo in Florida. He headed south to stay with his grandparents at a retirement community in Delray Beach, and there, Mr. Rothman said, he had an epiphany. His grandmother was making him a sandwich, he said, and the TV was on in the background. 
 ''I felt safe,'' he said.
 When he did not land a television writing job in Los Angeles, he said, he decided to head for the safety of the retired life. 
 For six months his life began to resemble a long version of one of those remote segments he had once written for ''Late Show.'' He hung out at the pool with retired women, played golf, softball and bingo, and even summoned the help of a New York advertising executive to help gin up interest in a shuffleboard tournament. (To promote shuffleboard, the executive tells him, he needs to ''take tennis out at the knees.'') 
 Mr. Rothman turned those experiences into set pieces for his book, which became exclusively about his time among the retired, and they figure into his television pilot, which stars Timm Sharp as a young man who goes to Florida to sell his dead grandfather's retirement condominium, and decides instead to move in.
 Mr. Rothman said he had hoped to find wisdom at Century Village, perhaps through an elder sage, as happens in the best seller ''Tuesdays With Morrie,'' by Mitch Albom. It did not quite work out that way.
 ''I wanted to find a Morrie, first of all because I could've used the advice, and second because, if you find Morrie, your book is going to sell five million copies,'' Mr. Rothman said. ''I realized the guy who wrote that book only spent one day a week with Morrie. If he'd spent more time with Morrie he'd realize that by Wednesday Morrie would've run out of things to say, and by Friday you'd want to strangle the guy.''

HEADLINE: That Russian Bargain Basement May Be Overrun

BYLINE: By ERIN E. ARVEDLUND

DATELINE: MOSCOW 

 BODY:
INVESTORS in Russia have generally done quite well this year, despite a broad sell-off in many emerging markets elsewhere around the world. 
 But those investors shouldn't celebrate yet. A major reason that Russian stocks and bonds have performed so well lately is that they did so badly last year, when rising interest rates and fears of Kremlin intervention in the economy prompted many international investors to sell their holdings. Now, Russia looks relatively cheap, and some foreigners have stepped back in from the sidelines. Local players have helped drive the market recovery, too. 
 Still, many equity investors, including Arjun Divecha, manager of the GMO Emerging Markets fund from Grantham, Mayo, Van Otterloo, remain decidedly cautious about Russia. Mr. Divecha says he has concerns about the country, ''not because of the political climate,'' but because of stock valuations, macroeconomic problems and stock and earnings momentum. 
 Stock valuations have been buoyed by Russia's oil riches, he said, but ''won't be so anymore if oil prices go down.'' And while the economy has boomed since Vladimir V. Putin became president in 2000, growing 7.1 percent in 2004 alone, Mr. Divecha said that such growth rates would not be likely to last very long in any country. ''Expectations are built in, as they are in Russia, that the economy will grow at least 7 percent a year,'' he warned. ''They are likely to disappoint.''
 Perhaps most ominously, momentum in stock prices has been undercut by the Kremlin-supported campaign against Yukos, the oil company, and its founder, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky. The government seized and then sold Yukos's largest oil field late last year, rocking investor confidence and calling into question the solidity of property rights. Mr. Khodorkovsky has been jailed since October 2003, facing accusations of tax evasion, fraud and embezzlement. A verdict in his criminal case is due on May 16.
 Despite those problems, Russia has been relatively immune from the declines that have hit other emerging markets. Spurred by interest-rate increases in the United States and a sell-off in the American bond market, global investors dumped what they saw as riskier assets -- and many emerging markets were hit hard. 
 But because the Russian stock market has already had a sell-off, its current market valuations are relatively attractive, some investors say. After hitting a record high of more than 780 in April 2004, Russia's benchmark RTS index slid more than 22 percent and ended the year barely higher, up 0.3 percent, at 605.66. This year, Russia has been playing catch-up. The RTS is up 9.2 percent, versus a gain of 1.1 percent for the MSCI Emerging Markets index. 
 Russia's equity market remains ''extremely cheap on a cash-flow basis,'' noted James Fenkner, principal at Red Star Asset Management, a hedge fund investing in Russia. 
 Christopher Weafer, chief strategist at Alfa Bank, concurred with that view, saying: ''Earnings are starting to turn, but the reason Russia is cheap is risk. Shifting politics can easily change economic dynamics.''
 Investors now make more distinctions among emerging markets, said Rudolph Riad-Younes, who runs the Julius Baer International Equity fund. ''More people are willing to accept many emerging markets are different than they were 10 or 20 years ago -- especially with valuations very stretched in the developed world.''
 Russia's macroeconomic position has improved markedly since its debt default in 1998. Amid high oil prices, the federal budget has a net surplus of 687 billion rubles -- almost $24.7 billion -- equivalent to more than 4 percent of gross domestic product. As of April 22, Russia's foreign-exchange reserves were $141.3 billion. The world's second-largest oil producer, after Saudi Arabia, Russia may repay its estimated $100 billion in foreign debt by 2007, Andrei N. Illarionov, an aide to Mr. Putin, said last month.
 That has created a golden backdrop for careful fixed-income investors, said Mohamed El-Erian, a former director of the International Monetary Fund and a portfolio manager overseeing international emerging-market debt at Pimco.
 Mr. El-Erian invests in Russian sovereign debt like the 30-year bond but avoids corporate bonds in the country. ''There are two Russias when you look at the bond market,'' he said. ''Sovereigns have done well, and will continue to do well,'' returning 10 percent, on average, in the last 12 months. ''That's pretty good,'' he added, ''given that almost everything else has sold off.'' 
 Mr. El-Erian said he did not hold any Russian corporate bonds. ''The rule of law is not applied uniformly, and large companies are often built up around an 'oligarch,' or other business personality,'' he said. 
 Minority shareholders' rights are fragile, he said. ''The minute you go from sovereign to corporate,'' he explained, ''you assume a lot more risk which is not priced in.'' 
 The Yukos affair has seriously strained ties between Russia's business elite and the Kremlin, which has portrayed Yukos as a corporate tax cheat. Once Russia's largest private oil company, Yukos is now half its former size and pumps about 600,000 barrels a day, its largest field having been renationalized. It is still paying off a $28 billion back tax bill levied by the government, which has reserved the right to use such tactics against other companies. 
 ''Many other companies have also apparently experienced increased harassment, often from the tax administration under the guise of exposing and collecting unpaid taxes from previous years,'' the World Bank said in a report written in March and released in April. 
 The government recently levied an unexpected claim for $1 billion in back taxes against BP's joint venture in Russia, TNK-BP.
 ''No one wants a repeat of the Yukos case,'' Igor I. Shuvalov, an aide to Mr. Putin, told an American Chamber of Commerce conference here in March. ''We are aware that it tarnishes the country's image. But the same measures will be applied to all taxpayers in the future.'' 
 Mr. Putin has tried to smooth worries that the state will intervene at will in the economy -- promising a three-year statute of limitations on investigations of controversial 1990's privatizations. Foreign direct investment is improving, although it is still low. It shot up to a record $9.4 billion in 2004 from $6.8 billion in 2003 -- but that is just two-thirds the foreign direct investment in the Czech Republic.
 One possible stimulus for the markets involves Gazprom, the natural gas company. United States investors cannot hold its local shares directly; they have been limited to more expensive American depository receipts. But German Gref, the economic development and trade minister, has said the scrapping of limits on foreigners owning Gazprom shares ''will happen this year.'' 
 Gazprom's tiny weighting in the MSCI Emerging Markets index could rise significantly once that limit has ended. That poses a quandary for investors like Julie Pfeffer, portfolio manager at DuPont Capital Management. She said the potential for Gazprom to become a major component in the index would probably require her to buy Gazprom -- albeit reluctantly. 
 ''I've always been very unhappy with management there, and if you look at the money they're making -- and wasting -- on expenses and capital expense write-offs, I can't in good conscience buy it,'' she said. ''I've been happy up until now that it's been a minor component of the index. If it gets a good weight I'll have to buy some, and I don't want any.''

HEADLINE: Meena Seshamani, Craig Mullaney

 BODY:
Dr. Meena Seshamani and Capt. Craig Michael Mullaney were married yesterday at the Madison Hotel in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. S. Matthew Glover, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. A Hindu Vedic ceremony was performed on Friday at Birchwood Manor in Whippany, N.J., by Sri Ramanath Gananaskandan. 
 The bride, 27, will keep her name. She is completing her medical degree at the University of Pennsylvania. She is to begin a residency in otolaryngology-head and neck surgery at Johns Hopkins University Medical Center in Baltimore in July. She graduated magna cum laude from Brown and received a doctorate in health economics from Oxford under a Marshall scholarship. She is a daughter of Dr. Rama Seshamani and Mani Seshamani of Warren, N.J. The bride's father works in Tarrytown, N.Y., as a vice president in the environmental group of Hitachi America. Her mother is an executive director of drug regulatory affairs at Novartis Pharmaceuticals in East Hanover, N.J. 
 The bridegroom, 26, is an Army assistant operations officer with the Old Guard, the ceremonial escort to the president, based at Fort Myer in Arlington, Va. He served as an infantry rifle platoon leader in Afghanistan in 2003 and 2004. Captain Mullaney graduated from the Military Academy at West Point and received a master's degree in economic and social history at Oxford, where he was a Rhodes scholar. He is a son of Ellen Mullaney of West Warwick, R.I. His mother is a registered nurse at Hasbro Children's Hospital in Providence, R.I. 
 Dr. Seshamani and Captain Mullaney first met at Lincoln College at Oxford in October 2000. She was in the second year of her doctoral program, and he had just arrived.
 ''Craig was looking up and down the hallway and seemed a bit lost,'' she said. She asked if he needed help. He ended up joining her and her friends for lunch.
 As they talked, she recalled, she was impressed with his ''sincerity and ambition.'' He remembered her ''honesty and warmth.''
 Whenever they saw each other on campus over the next weeks, they continued talking. 
 ''I realized that we had this uncanny and rare ability to discuss important issues that form the core of our identities,'' she said, including religion, independence and traditions. 
 In February 2001, after returning from Christmas break, he invited her to join him on a trip to Paris with a busload of other graduate students. It was the first salvo of what he called his ''wooing offensive.'' 
 After that weekend he became more explicit about his feelings for her. That led, he said, to ''some sort of interview.''
 ''It was harder than my interview for the Rhodes scholarship,'' Captain Mullaney said. In addition to questions about families, it covered the role of war in foreign policy and the cultural gap between the military and civilians.
 Dr. Seshamani later explained that she needed to know more. She had ''grown up in suburban New Jersey in a fairly conservative environment that did not condone parties or dating,'' she said. ''I couldn't make the same assumptions about his viewpoints as I could from people who had the kinds of jobs and backgrounds I am more familiar with.''
 But he survived the grilling, and they began dating and immersing themselves in each other's cultures. 
 ''She read many of my books about the military and West Point, which undercut the stereotypes she had about soldiers,'' Captain Mullaney said. ''I was insatiably curious about her Indian culture. I learned to speak basic Hindi and cook Indian food and enrolled in an Indian history course. I took my sister on a three-week trip there.''
 Dr. Seshamani had given little thought to marriage before dating Captain Mullaney, she said, believing it would constrain her professionally. When she did, she said, she assumed her husband ''would be an Indian professional, not an Irish Catholic infantry officer.'' But he gave her a new perspective. 
 She said, ''We found our ability to support and challenge each other only grew with time.''

HEADLINE: The Economic Unit Called Supermom

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
IF you want to know how much the average food worker in the nation earns -- $8.31 an hour -- the Bureau of Labor Statistics has the answer. A hedge fund manager's salary can be inferred by the Jaguar in his driveway. But how to calculate the value on the 10 hours clocked last week at an elementary school book fair by the mom in the fetching cardigan?
 Every successful school in America has at least one: that mother who appears, Zelig-like, at every imaginable school event; running registration at grandparents' day; doling out peanut butter sandwiches during the class trip; manning the ring toss at the spring fair. 
 She combed your daughter's hair on picture day last fall, and steered her away from a Junie B. Jones book as she stacked the school library shelves, and you never even knew it. And she baked a lasagna for the neighbor whose husband is in the hospital and spent a few hours carpooling to soccer games in between.
 It stands to reason that a culture that places high social value on earned income would try to place a market value on mother's work, especially those tasks that contribute to some bottom line: think of the school auction, which nets well over $100,000 in many upscale communities.
 Yet neither domestic nor volunteer work figure into the gross domestic product (plenty of women's organizations think it should), and economists can't even agree on how best to calculate what it is worth. 
 So how to value mom's benevolence and hard work? With a flat wage? By the market value of the product she produced? (An excellent idea for the mom who adds truffles to her neighbor's casserole.) How about some annual salary based on a roughly commensurate industry, like, say, social work? 
 One financial planning company, Edelman Financial Services, has in fact added up the annual salaries of workers among 17 occupations engaged in by a busy mother (pet care, housekeeping, etc.) and come up with an estimated $707,126 annual paycheck. While this calculation might gain Edelman some financial-planning business from a newly affirmed female clientele, it is not one embraced by most economists. 
 ''If you go for an hourly wage,'' said Heidi Hartmann, an economist founder and president of the Institute for Women's Policy Research, ''then is the Ph.D.-educated women's casserole worth more than the mother with the high school diploma?''
 As for the product value model, she said, ''You could probably get the meal a mother brings to the neighbor pretty cheaply, so the meal is not as valuable as helping an older neighbor with her income tax, because financial planning is a more valuable service.''
 Of course, so much of mother's work is rewarded in only vaguely tangible ways: a nod of appreciation in the school newsletter, the twisted thrill of an empty dishwasher, a snuggle from a sated toddler.
 This is why many social scientists have explored the ''social capital'' gained by participating in these otherwise uncompensated activities. Social scientists argue, for example, that test scores go up in schools where parent volunteerism is highest, and that crime is reduced in communities with high civic participation.
 ''Social capital is usually defined as the networks and relationships we have, as well as the trust and sense of mutuality that arise from them,'' said Amy Caiazza, a study director working with Ms. Hartmann.
 Ms. Caiazza argued that that trust gives people ''a sense that our government works more or less on our behalf.''
 But just as art imitates life, caring sometimes can look more like capitalism. For example, within some schools there is fierce competition for the best ''jobs,'' often performed with the same tools (BlackBerries, spreadsheets and starchy e-mailed directives to subordinates) and precision that the mothers once employed in high-profile jobs. 
 A mother in a Manhattan private school describes a pecking order for volunteers, in which some mothers prove their mettle as class representatives or T-shirt sellers before graduating to highly coveted posts, like head of the school benefit committee.
 It may not be long before these mothers, who knew exactly how society assessed their contributions when they labored in the boardroom, may see their current work assigned a dollar value, too. 
 In 2003, the Bureau of Labor Statistics conducted its first-ever Time Use Survey, which examined the doings of 21,000 Americans over a 24-hour period. ''There were a number of economists who were interested in valuing nonmarket production,'' said Diane Herz, the survey's project manager. 
 Those activities were broken down into 458 activity codes, which may at some point be assigned monetary values. A group of scientists at the National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences has suggested that some domestic work be valued as specialization (plumbing, say), general (garden-variety housework) or opportunity cost (that is, the income that a woman in the same demographic cohort as her working-mom counterpart is missing out on). 
 What if you put that all together in Manhattan dollars, where a $500 weekly salary for a full-time baby sitter for two children is common? Add $80 every two weeks to pay for housekeeping, and, for the mother who has taken on the task of running the school benefit, $10,000, the lower end of the scale charged by Creative Event Planning, a party planning outfit in New York. Add $100 for an hourly plumbing fee (reduced somewhat under the belief that mom is not quite as skillful with the wrench as one New York company that fetches $150 an hour), and $350 that would be paid weekly to a chauffeur, and there is a pretty good living.
 Let's leave out the opportunity cost. That one is mitigated by two priceless words: Thanks, Mom.

HEADLINE: Home Prices Show Signs of Leveling

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
THE median sales price of a single family house in Westchester remained flat in the first three months of 2005, the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service reported last week. After reaching an all-time high of $686,000 in the third quarter of 2004, the median was $615,000 for the quarter that ended in March, the same as it was for the previous quarter. 
 While the quarterly median price was up from a year earlier, the rate of increase was smaller than the rises experienced throughout 2004. What that portends for the future is not clear, said P. Gilbert Mercurio, the executive vice president of the Listing Service. It could represent a pause before prices begin to rise again. Or it could indicate that Westchester's seemingly unstoppable housing market has cooled off. 
 At the very least, the housing market ''may be starting to bend from its own weight,'' Mr. Mercurio speculated in the M.L.S.'s first-quarter report. ''Middle-range prices of $615,000 or higher may have begun to outrun the incomes of buyers, even after the deployment of equity in their current residence, and it may be time for prices to pause while incomes catch up.'' 
 The first-quarter median sale price of a single-family house was up by $45,000, or 8 percent, from the prior year. In 2004, the year-to-year quarterly increases ranged from 13 percent to 16 percent. Home prices tend to follow a statistical pattern throughout the year, Mr. Mercurio said, with prices highest in the second and third quarter reports. 
 For now, the deceleration means that sellers can no longer push prices on their homes and expect to sell them quickly, brokers said. ''An 8 percent increase is still healthy, but it's not 15 percent, and sellers can't be as aggressive as before,'' said Ted Holmes, the manager of Prudential Holmes & Kennedy's Armonk office.
 The sales figures compiled each quarter are based on closings; first-quarter closings tend to reflect sales agreements made late in 2004 and in early January of 2005, when the region's economy, as measured by job growth and unemployment rates, was stable and slowly expanding. In November and December, the Federal Reserve Board twice increased its discount rate by a quarter point, but those increases were not reflected in long-term mortgage rates.
 Meanwhile, during the first quarter the American economy slowed to its weakest pace in two years, the Commerce Department reported. The nation's gross domestic product, the broadest measure of goods and services produced in the United States, grew 3.1 percent, a somewhat slower pace than had been expected.
 The slowdown in the Westchester residential real estate market appears to have affected all price categories and did not signal stress in the high-end segment, as some analysts had speculated. ''To the contrary,'' the report said, ''the high-end market maintained its share of sales volume. Properties selling for $1 million or more accounted for 18 percent of first quarter sales in 2005 and 16 percent in 2004; the comparable figures for properties selling in the range of $750,000 to $999,000 were 18 percent and 16 percent respectively as well. The two-percentage-point difference represented ordinary inflationary bracket creep.''
 Prices rose more sharply in housing sectors other than single-family homes. The median price of a condominium rose by 13.3 percent in the first quarter of this year to $354,000, from $312,450 a year ago. Co-op prices were up by 16.6 percent, to $158,000 from $135,500. The strongest category of all was multifamily homes -- housing two to five families -- where the median sales price rose 24.1 percent to $540,000 from $435,000 for the first quarter of 2004.
 The increase in multifamily home prices reflected investor interest in such properties in urban areas like White Plains, Yonkers and Mount Vernon, said Chris Meyers, the chief operating officer of Houlihan/Lawrence, which has 29 offices in the county. ''With interest rates so low, investors are still able to maintain a cash flow even if rents are not as high as they once were,'' he said.
 The condo and co-op segments fared well because, in a market of ever-escalating prices, they have provided lower-cost alternatives, said George Kiaffas, an associate broker at Julia B. Fee in Scarsdale. ''They have provided first-time home buyers with an option,'' he said.
 While younger buyers tend to buy less expensive condos and co-ops, empty-nesters shedding a large home are often drawn to luxury units, said Nick Wolff, the owner of Century 21 Wolff, which has four offices in Westchester.
 Looking at the market as a whole, Mr. Meyers at Houlihan/Lawrence suggested that home sellers may not be calling the market tune as much as they had in the recent past. ''It's been such a strong sellers' market for so many years,'' Mr. Meyers said, ''but that was very difficult on buyers, who tended to chase after things. Now they're not jumping anymore.''
 Advising sellers now to price houses realistically, Mr. Meyers said: ''The idea is to draw multiple bids, and ultimately, that's what will bring the best price. If you price a property ahead of comparable houses, you may end up having to mark it down over time, and property that has markdowns creates a feeling of 'Let's wait and see,' among buyers. Sellers don't want to find themselves in that position.''
 Ellen Grollman of Prudential Holmes & Kennedy cited a colonial in Pleasantville for which she was the listing agent as an example of a property whose owners used an effective strategy. The five-bedroom, three-and-a-half bath house on almost an acre of land went on the market on Feb. 28 for $1.245 million, which was regarded as a not overly aggressive price. The owners received multiple bids and went to contract seven days later for more than the asking price. 
 In all, there were 1,998 closings in Westchester in the first quarter, 1 percent more than for the corresponding period in 2004. Dollar volume for all categories of sales was up 15.6 percent, to $1.173 billion.
 The inventory of homes on the market on March 31, 4,765, was 19 percent more than a year earlier and the highest since the end of the first quarter of 1999. But, the M.L.S. report said, the number was low compared with the levels of 8,000 to 10,000 units in the early to mid-1990's and was ''far below the quantities needed to relieve the demand-supply imbalance in our region.''
 Only time will show whether the single-digit increase in the median sales price of a single-family home for the first quarter represented a short-term slowdown or a longer-term market slowing. Mr. Kiaffas at Julia B. Fee believes it is the former. ''We're already seeing things pick up again,'' he said. ''The figures from the Multiple Listing Service reflect just a temporary pause. You'll see that in the next report.''
 Mr. Mercurio agreed that the 8 percent first quarter price increase may be just a statistical aberration. But he said, ''no matter how the market develops, it should be recalled that ordinary single-digit percentage price increases were not very long ago considered normal and healthy in this area.''

HEADLINE: 9/11 and the News Cycle

 BODY:

Five news events last week were reminders of the long shadow cast by the World Trade Center attacks.

GROUND ZERO

Back to the Drawing Board -- New York political leaders and the lead developer of the Freedom Tower, the main building to be built on the former World Trade Center site, said on Wednesday that the tower would be redesigned, in part to address concerns raised by the New York police about the building's security.

Behind the News -- The weak market for office space in lower Manhattan may be as big a threat to the project as security concerns. It hasn't helped that Goldman Sachs & Company recently stepped back from plans to build a $2 billion headquarters across the street, or that so far the only tenant in the rebuilt 7 World Trade Center is the developer. Still, officials say, whatever the redesigned Freedom Tower winds up looking like, it will definitely still be 1,776 feet tall.

SECURITY

Driver's Licenses -- Congressional aides said on Monday that the House and Senate were moving to impose stricter new national rules for issuing and renewing driver's licenses. States would have to verify that the applicant is in the country legally.

Behind the News -- A host of issues converge on one prosaic bit of bureaucracy, the driver's license. Any hint of a national identification card is anathema to civil libertarians, so homeland-security hawks turn to state-issued driver's licenses as a more palatable proxy. But critics of the ID card say they see a serious side effect (and perhaps an ulterior motive): freezing many immigrants, legal and illegal, out of the economy.

AL QAEDA

A Big Arrest -- Pakistani officials said on Wednesday that they had captured a Libyan man, Abu Faraj al-Libbi, who American and Pakistani officials said was the third-most-senior leader in Al Qaeda's terrorist network.

Behind the News -- The assertions about his rank in Al Qaeda raised some skepticism, since he was not on the F.B.I.'s most wanted list, unlike a man with a fairly similar name who is said to have helped bomb two American embassies in East Africa in 1998. But Pakistan, which is often criticized for failing to catch many Qaeda figures thought to be hiding there, had ample motive to pursue Mr. Libbi: he is suspected of directing two failed attempts to assassinate the country's president.

IRAQ

Bomb in Kurdish -- Region A suicide bomber blew himself up Wednesday at a police recruiting center in Erbil, killing at least 60 people and wounding at least 150 others, many of them prospective policemen. Ansar al-Sunna, a well-known terrorist group, claimed responsibility.

Behind the News -- The Shiite Arab and Kurdish blocs in Iraq have little in common except that for decades Saddam Hussein and his Sunni-Arab-dominated regime oppressed them both. But the Sunni boycott of the January elections left the Shiites and Kurds to share power in the new government that took office last month, so they are both now targets of mounting violence aimed at destabilizing the new government.

NEW YORK

Bombs in a Planter -- Two small bombs, apparently inexpertly made out of dummy grenades, black powder and matchlit fuses, went off early Thursday in a concrete planter on the sidewalk in front of an office building on Third Avenue in Manhattan.

Behind the News -- With no one injured and hardly any damage done, the event would once have barely merited a mention in the news. But that was before 9/11. Today, almost any explosion -- especially in New York, and even more especially outside the British Consulate on the day of Britain's general election -- takes on a more sinister cast and can rattle nerves and make headlines around the world.

HEADLINE: It's Not War, but It Can Be Hellish

BYLINE: By PETER EDIDIN

 BODY:
THE United States Army has increasingly been involved in missions, like peacekeeping, requiring it to police civilian societies. But controlling protesters or quelling a riot in a nation with which America is at peace requires different skills and (usually nonlethal) responses than war fighting. 
 To teach these skills, the Army recently created a Civil Disturbances Operations manual (www.fas.org/irp/doddir/army/fm3-19-15.pdf), 256 pages long, covering everything from the roots of unrest, to crowd sociology, to the chemicals for dispersing rioters. Excerpts follow. PETER EDIDIN

General Causes for Civil Unrest -- In these modern times, demonstrations, civil unrest, public disorder and riots happen for a number of reasons. Some of these reasons are economic hardships, social injustices, ethnic differences (leading to oppression), objections to world organizations or certain governments, political grievances and terrorist acts.

Crowd Development -- Crowds are a gathering of a multitude of individuals and small groups that have temporarily assembled in the same place.

Gatherings -- The assembly process of a gathering refers to the movement of people from different locations to a common location within a given period. Gatherings are often assisted by yelling catchy slogans and cheers that everyone can easily pick up and join in on.

Impromptu Gatherings -- Impromptu gatherings usually develop informally and are mostly done by word of mouth. An example of an impromptu gathering would be a gathering at a secured food distribution point after receiving information that a large truck carrying much-needed supplies and food is about to arrive.

Organized Gatherings -- Recent examples of these well-organized groups are anarchists, antiglobalization groups and anti-free-enterprise groups. Groups representing extreme religious faiths and ethnic organizations have been common, too.

Crowd Building -- Crowds are not made of isolated individuals but of a minority of individuals and a majority of small groups.
 Groups and individuals in the crowd are not unanimous in their motivation.

Crowd Dispersal -- The routine dispersal may be specified in advance. It can also be included in the assembly instructions given by the organizers of an event.
 An emergency dispersal occurs when people evacuate an area in result of an unexpected crisis, such as a fire, explosion, bomb threat or terrorist act. 
 Coercion dispersal is caused by the use of force at some level. This is not necessarily the best way to force the dispersal of a crowd.

Crowd Dynamics -- Crowds provide individuals with a sense of anonymity ... giving a sense of invulnerability.
 Crowds provide individuals with the idea that their moral responsibilities have shifted from themselves ... to the crowd as a whole. 
 Emotional contagion is the most dramatic psychological factor of crowd dynamics. It provides the crowd with a temporary bond of psychological unity.

Crowd Types -- Casual crowds are identified as individuals or small groups with nothing in common to bind them together.
 Sighting crowds are similar to casual crowds with one additional element -- an event. People migrate as a crowd to sporting events, are attracted to fires and accidents and attend music concerts. 
 Agitated crowds are Individuals with strong emotional feelings within a crowd can quickly spread ..., causing changes in the overall demeanor of the crowd.

Riots -- Riots vary ... in both targets and players. A communal riot, for instance, deals with deep-seated ethnic, religious and language differences. Commodity riots involve an attack on property by acts of vandalism, looting and arson. The Democratic Convention in Chicago in 1968 reflects a riot that directly targeted police and authority in general. Celebration riots occur across the U.S. as a result of home team victories in sporting events, among other reasons.
 What is the overarching identity of the crowd? It may be possible to determine identities and goals from advance assembling instructions, leaflets distributed to bystanders, placards and banners, and chants and songs. 
 What are their traditional behaviors? What people do during protests is not universal. Social protest organizations and striking unions will carry placards and banners. Other groups will protest in a more quiet way, like the 5,000 women in Sarajevo whose standard Sunday behavior was to sit and block traffic. They were protesting the loss of male relatives in the Bosnian war. 
 What are the possible targets of violence? Riots, in particular, may focus on target facilities. In the 1992 Los Angeles riots, gun stores were major targets. In Somalia, throngs of people stormed food supply facilities. In Haiti, riots broke out over trash dumps where U.S. forces had discarded the remnants of meals.

HEADLINE: Amagansett Beach to Test Solar-Powered Garbage Can

BYLINE: By Peter C. Beller

 BODY:
A solar-powered garbage can that automatically compacts trash will be tested this summer at an Amagansett beach where conventional cans often overflow with trash from the large crowds.
 The BigBelly, which is made of galvanized steel, will be installed at Atlantic Avenue beach in June. 
The machine automatically senses when its 42-gallon receptacle is full and an electric motor, powered by solar panels, compacts the trash to as much as a 10th of its original volume, reducing the need for pickups.
 An indicator on the BigBelly's exterior turns red when the can must be emptied, and it can be equipped to send a message by cellphone or wireless Internet when full.
 Debra Foster, an East Hampton Town Board member who pushed the pilot program, said the machine would reduce the number of trips town employees make to collect trash, saving labor and gasoline. She said she thought the $4,875 machine would pay for itself in a year.
 ''It's environmentally sound and economically sound,'' she said. 
 New York City tested one of the devices in Manhattan in February and March, and 50 of the machines will be installed in Queens this summer, said Richard Kennelly, a vice president at the Seahorse Power Company of Westborough, Mass., which manufactures the BigBelly. Peter C. Beller

HEADLINE: Monitoring A Double Dose Of Reports

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
REMEMBER that week in April, when the report of a larger-than-expected trade deficit in February was followed by news of much-weaker-than-expected retail sales in March?
 Those two pieces of data turned investors' focus from fear of inflation to fear of slowing economic growth -- and sent stocks tumbling. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 4.6 percent in six trading days, to close just 12 points above 10,000. 
 Well, the March trade deficit and April retail sales will be reported this week. The trade deficit number, due Wednesday, is expected to grow to a record $61.7 billion, according to forecasts gathered by Bloomberg News, from $61 billion in February. Retail sales, due Thursday, are expected to climb 0.7 percent, after the disappointing 0.3 percent increase in March.
 David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International, says he thinks that retail sales will show a 1 percent climb because of a strong recovery in auto sales in April. Unfortunately for General Motors and Ford Motor -- whose bond ratings dropped to junk status last week -- all of that rebound was in sales by their competitors.
 The bounce in auto sales means that Mr. Resler is less concerned about a slowdown in consumer spending becoming a dangerous drag on economic growth. 
 But he is worried about the recent weakness in capital spending by businesses, another main driver of the economy. He said that as the first quarter ended, capital spending was slowing, falling below its average for the quarter. So capital spending needs to have a nice jump in the second quarter just to avoid being a drag on growth. 
 If the capital-spending soft patch does not disappear soon, he said, he will lower his growth estimates for this year and next.
 As of now, he is forecasting that the soft patch will be over by summer. He predicts 3.5 percent growth in the third quarter and 3.7 percent growth in the fourth, after a sluggish 2.7 percent this quarter. 
 The strong jobs report for April, reported on Friday, makes him significantly more confident about his outlook, he said.

DATA WATCH -- The University of Michigan report on consumer confidence is due on Friday the 13th.
 This preliminary reading for May is expected to show a confidence level of 88, up slightly from 87.7 in April.
